<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0">
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; WIDTH: 100%">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 1PT SOLID">
<B>
<B>
	Asset Quality
</B>
<B>
</B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	A loan is considered impaired when it is probable that we will not receive all amounts due
	according to the contractual terms of the loans.&nbsp;&nbsp;Impaired loans include non-performing loans (loans past due 90 days
	or more and nonaccrual loans) and certain other loans identified by management that are still performing.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Non-performing loans are comprised of (a) nonaccrual loans, (b) loans that are contractually
	past due 90 days and (c) other loans for which terms have been restructured to provide a reduction or deferral of interest or principal,
	because of deterioration in the financial position of the borrower. Simmons Bank recognizes income principally on the accrual basis
	of accounting. When loans are classified as nonaccrual, generally, the accrued interest is charged off and no further interest
	is accrued. Loans, excluding credit card loans, are placed on a nonaccrual basis either: (1) when there are serious doubts regarding
	the collectability of principal or interest, or (2) when payment of interest or principal is 90 days or more past due and either
	(i) not fully secured or (ii) not in the process of collection. If a loan is determined by management to be uncollectible, the
	portion of the loan determined to be uncollectible is then charged to the allowance for loan losses.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Credit card loans are classified as impaired when payment of interest or principal is 90
	days past due. Litigation accounts are placed on nonaccrual until such time as deemed uncollectible. Credit card loans are generally
	charged off when payment of interest or principal exceeds 180 days past due, but are turned over to the credit card recovery department,
	to be pursued until such time as they are determined, on a case-by-case basis, to be uncollectible.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Total non-performing assets, excluding all loans acquired and foreclosed assets covered by
	FDIC loss share agreements, increased by $5.9&nbsp;million from December 31, 2014, to December 31, 2015.&nbsp;&nbsp;Foreclosed
	assets held for sale (legacy and acquired, not covered) decreased by $36,000. During 2015, $6.1 million of previously closed branch
	buildings and land was reclassified to OREO from premises held for sale. There was no deterioration or further write-down of these
	properties. This increase was partially offset by the reduction in other foreclosed assets of $6.0 million. Under ASC Topic 360,
	there is a one year maximum holding period to classify premises as held for sale. Nonaccrual loans increased by $5.7 million during
	2015, primarily CRE loans. We remain aggressive in the identification, quantification and resolution of problem loans.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Total non-performing assets, excluding all loans acquired and foreclosed assets covered by
	FDIC loss share agreements, decreased by $16.2&nbsp;million from December 31, 2013, to December 31, 2014.&nbsp;&nbsp;Total non-performing
	loans increased by $3.8 million from December 31, 2013 to December 31, 2014, while foreclosed assets held for sale, excluding all
	acquired foreclosed assets, decreased by $19.9 million during the period as we were able to rid ourselves of several significant
	non-performing assets through liquidation in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Total non-performing assets, excluding all loans acquired and foreclosed assets covered by
	FDIC loss share agreements, increased by $28.5&nbsp;million from December 31, 2012, to December 31, 2013.&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase
	in non-performing assets is related to the Metropolitan acquisition, in which we acquired $42.9 million in non-covered foreclosed
	assets. Total non-performing loans decreased by $2.9 million from December 31, 2012 to December 31, 2013, while foreclosed assets
	held for sale, excluding all acquired foreclosed assets, decreased by $2.2 million during the period.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 35; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	35
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage36"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	From time to time, certain borrowers are experiencing declines in income and cash flow.&nbsp;&nbsp;As
	a result, many borrowers are seeking to reduce contractual cash outlays, the most prominent being debt payments.&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	an effort to preserve our net interest margin and earning assets, we are open to working with existing customers in order to maximize
	the collectability of the debt.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	When we restructure a loan to a borrower that is experiencing financial difficulty and grant
	a concession that we would not otherwise consider, a troubled debt restructuring results and the Company classifies the loan as
	a TDR.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company grants various types of concessions, primarily interest rate reduction and/or payment modifications
	or extensions, with an occasional forgiveness of principal.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Under ASC Topic 310-10-35,
<I>
	Subsequent Measurement
</I>
	, a TDR is considered to be impaired,
	and an impairment analysis must be performed.&nbsp;&nbsp;We assess the exposure for each modification, either by collateral discounting
	or by calculation of the present value of future cash flows, and determine if a specific allocation to the allowance for loan losses
	is needed.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Once an obligation has been restructured because of such credit problems, it continues to
	be considered a TDR until paid in full; or, if an obligation yields a market interest rate and no longer has any concession regarding
	payment amount or amortization, then it is not considered a TDR at the beginning of the calendar year after the year in which the
	improvement takes place.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our TDR balance increased to $5.6 million at December 31, 2015, compared to $3.2 million at
	December&nbsp;31, 2014 primarily related to two larger CRE loans.&nbsp;&nbsp;The majority of our TDRs are in the CRE portfolio.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We return TDRs to accrual status only if (1) all contractual amounts due can reasonably be
	expected to be repaid within a prudent period, and (2) repayment has been in accordance with the contract for a sustained period,
	typically at least six months.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We continue to maintain good asset quality, compared to the industry.&nbsp;&nbsp;The allowance
	for loan losses as a percent of total loans was 0.97% as of December 31, 2015.&nbsp;&nbsp;Non-performing loans equaled 0.58% of
	total loans.&nbsp;&nbsp;Non-performing assets were 0.85% of total assets.&nbsp;&nbsp;The allowance for loan losses was 166% of
	non-performing loans.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our net charge-offs to total loans for 2015 were 0.24%.&nbsp;&nbsp;Excluding credit cards, the
	net charge-offs to total loans were 0.16%.&nbsp;&nbsp;Net credit card charge-offs to total credit card loans for 2015 were 1.28%,
	compared to 1.27% in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We do not own any securities backed by subprime mortgage assets, and offer no mortgage loan
	products that target subprime borrowers.&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 36; VALUE: 3 -->

	&nbsp;

</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Table 10 presents information concerning non-performing assets, including nonaccrual and
	restructured loans and other real estate owned (excluding all loans acquired and excluding other real estate covered by FDIC loss
	share agreements).
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: BOTTOM">
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD COLSPAN="3" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">

<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: RIGHT">
	1.10
</TD>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: -0.25IN; MARGIN: 0 0 0 0.25IN">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: RULE-PAGE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 3PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 1PT; BORDER-TOP: BLACK 1PT SOLID; WIDTH: 100%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /RULE-PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: -0.25IN; MARGIN: 0 0 0 0.25IN">
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 15PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	(1)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 5PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	Includes
	nonaccrual TDRs of approximately $2.5 million, $1.0 million, $0.7 million, $3.1 million
	and $5.2 million at December 31, 2015, 2014, 2013, 2012 and 2011, respectively.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 15PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	(2)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 5PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	Student
	loans past due 90 days or more are included in non-performing loans.&nbsp;&nbsp;Student
	loans are guaranteed by the federal government and will be purchased at 97% of principal
	and accrued interest when they exceed 270 days past due; therefore, non-performing ratios
	have been calculated excluding these loans.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 15PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	(3)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 5PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	Excludes
	all loans acquired and excludes other real estate acquired, covered by FDIC loss share
	agreements, except for their inclusion in total assets.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	There was no interest income on the nonaccrual loans recorded for the years ended December&nbsp;31,
	2015, 2014&nbsp;and&nbsp;2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	At December 31, 2015, impaired loans, net of government guarantees and acquired loans, were
	$18.2 million compared to $14.7 million at December 31, 2014.&nbsp;&nbsp;On an ongoing basis, management evaluates the underlying
	collateral on all impaired loans and allocates specific reserves, where appropriate, in order to absorb potential losses if the
	collateral were ultimately foreclosed.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 37; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	37
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage38"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; WIDTH: 100%">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 1PT SOLID">
<B>
<B>
	Allowance for Loan Losses
</B>
<B>
</B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Overview
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The allowance for loan losses is a reserve established through a provision for loan losses
	charged to expense, which represents management&#8217;s best estimate of probable losses that have been incurred within the existing
	portfolio of loans. The allowance, in the judgment of management, is necessary to reserve for estimated loan losses and risks inherent
	in the loan portfolio.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#8217;s allowance for loan loss methodology includes allowance allocations calculated
	in accordance with ASC Topic 310-10,
<I>
	Receivables
</I>
	, and allowance allocations calculated in accordance with ASC Topic 450-20,
<I>
	Loss Contingencies
</I>
	.&nbsp;&nbsp;Accordingly, the methodology is based on our internal grading system, specific impairment
	analysis, qualitative and quantitative factors.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	As mentioned above, allocations to the allowance for loan losses are categorized as either
	specific allocations or general allocations.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Specific Allocations
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	A loan is considered impaired when it is probable that we will not receive all amounts due
	according to the contractual terms of the loan, including scheduled principal and interest payments.&nbsp;&nbsp;For a collateral
	dependent loan, our evaluation process includes a valuation by appraisal or other collateral analysis.&nbsp;&nbsp;This valuation
	is compared to the remaining outstanding principal balance of the loan.&nbsp;&nbsp;If a loss is determined to be probable, the
	loss is included in the allowance for loan losses as a specific allocation.&nbsp;&nbsp;If the loan is not collateral dependent,
	the measurement of loss is based on the difference between the expected and contractual future cash flows of the loan.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	General Allocations
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The general allocation is calculated monthly based on management&#8217;s assessment of several
	factors such as (1) historical loss experience based on volumes and types, (2) volume and trends in delinquencies and nonaccruals,
	(3) lending policies and procedures including those for loan losses, collections and recoveries, (4) national, state and local
	economic trends and conditions, (5) concentrations of credit within the loan portfolio, (6) the experience, ability and depth of
	lending management and staff and (7) other factors and trends that will affect specific loans and categories of loans. We establish
	general allocations for each major loan category. This category also includes allocations to loans which are collectively evaluated
	for loss such as credit cards, one-to-four family owner occupied residential real estate loans and other consumer loans.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Reserve for Unfunded Commitments
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	In addition to the allowance for loan losses, we have established a reserve for unfunded
	commitments, classified in other liabilities.&nbsp;&nbsp;This reserve is maintained at a level sufficient to absorb losses arising
	from unfunded loan commitments.&nbsp;&nbsp;The adequacy of the reserve for unfunded commitments is determined monthly based on
	methodology similar to our methodology for determining the allowance for loan losses.&nbsp;&nbsp;Net adjustments to the reserve
	for unfunded commitments are included in other non-interest expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 38; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	38
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage39"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	An analysis of the allowance for loan losses for the last five years is shown in table 11.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT">

<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 3PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 1PT; BORDER-TOP: BLACK 1PT SOLID; WIDTH: 100%">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /RULE-PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 15PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	(1)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 5PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	Provision
	for loan losses of $736,000 attributable to loans acquired, was excluded from this table
	for 2015 (total year-to-date provision for loan losses is $9,022,000). The $736,000 was
	subsequently charged-off, resulting in no increase in the allowance related to loans
	acquired. Provision for loan losses of $363,000 attributable to acquired loans, covered
	by FDIC loss share, was excluded from this table for the year ended December 31, 2014
	(total provision for loan losses for the year ended December 31, 2014 is $7,245,000).
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 15PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	(2)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 5PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	Allowance
	for loan losses at December 31, 2015 and 2014 includes $954,000 allowance for loans acquired
	(not shown in the table above). The total allowance for loan losses at December 31, 2015
	and 2014 was $32,305,000 and $29,982,000, respectively.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 15PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	(3)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 5PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	Excludes
	all acquired loans.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Provision for Loan Losses
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The amount of provision added to the allowance each year was based on management's judgment,
	with consideration given to the composition of the portfolio, historical loan loss experience, assessment of current economic conditions,
	past due and non-performing loans and net loss experience.&nbsp;&nbsp;It is management's practice to review the allowance on a
	monthly basis, and after considering the factors previously noted, to determine the level of provision made to the allowance.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Allowance for Loan Losses Allocation
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Prior to the fourth quarter of 2012, we measured the appropriateness of the allowance for
	loan losses in its entirety using (a)ASC 450-20 which includes quantitative (historical loss rates) and qualitative factors (management
	adjustment factors) such as (1) lending policies and procedures, (2) economic outlook and business conditions, (3) level and trend
	in delinquencies, (4) concentrations of credit and (5) external factors and competition; which are combined with the historical
	loss rates to create the baseline factors that are allocated to the various loan categories; (b) specific allocations on impaired
	loans in accordance with ASC 310-10; and (c) the unallocated amount.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The unallocated amount was evaluated on the loan portfolio in its entirety and was based
	on additional factors, such as (1) trends in volume, maturity and composition, (2) national, state and local economic trends and
	conditions, (3) the experience, ability and depth of lending management and staff and (4) other factors and trends that will affect
	specific loans and categories of loans, such as a heightened risk in agriculture, credit card and commercial real estate loan portfolios.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 39; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	39
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	As of December 31, 2012, we refined our allowance calculation.&nbsp;&nbsp;As part of the
	refinement process, we evaluated the criteria previously applied to the entire loan portfolio, and used to calculate the unallocated
	portion of the allowance, and applied those criteria to each specific loan category. For example, the impact of national, state
	and local economic trends and conditions was evaluated by and allocated to specific loan categories.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	As a result of this refined allowance calculation, the Company allocated (i) $1.8 million
	previously included as unallocated allowance to its credit card portfolio segment, (ii) $5.3 million previously included as unallocated
	allowance to its real estate portfolio segment, including (a) $3.2 million to commercial real estate and (b) $2.1 million to 1-4
	family real estate and (iii) $1.6 million previously included as unallocated allowance to its commercial portfolio segment, including
	(a) $1.3&nbsp;million to agricultural and (b) $0.3 million to other commercial. These allocations totaling $8.7&nbsp;million were
	previously included in our unallocated allowance prior to the fourth quarter of 2012.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company may also consider additional qualitative factors in future periods for allowance
	allocations, including, among other factors, (1) seasoning of the loan portfolio, (2) the offering of new loan products, (3) specific
	industry conditions affecting portfolio segments and (4) the Company&#8217;s expansion into new markets.&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result
	of the&nbsp;refined allowance calculation, the allocation of our allowance may not be comparable with periods prior to December
	31, 2012.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The following table sets forth the sum of the amounts of the allowance for loan losses attributable
	to individual loans within each category, or loan categories in general and, prior to December 31, 2012, the unallocated allowance.&nbsp;&nbsp;As
	previously discussed, we refined our allowance calculation during 2012 such that we no longer maintain unallocated allowance.&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	table also reflects the percentage of loans in each category to the total loan portfolio, excluding loans acquired, for each of
	the periods indicated.&nbsp;&nbsp;These allowance amounts have been computed using the Company&#8217;s internal grading system,
	specific impairment analysis, qualitative and quantitative factor allocations.&nbsp;&nbsp;The amounts shown are not necessarily
	indicative of the actual future losses that may occur within individual categories.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT">

<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 0">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 0.25IN">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	(1)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	Percentage of loans in each category
	to total loans, excluding loans acquired.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP">
<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
	(2)
</TD>
<TD>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	Allowance for loan losses at December 31, 2015 and 2014 includes $954,000
	allowance for loans acquired (not shown in the table above). The total allowance for loan losses at
	December 31, 2015 and 2014 was $32,305,000 and $29,982,000, respectively.
</FONT>
</TD>

</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; WIDTH: 100%">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 1PT SOLID">
<B>
<B>
	Investments and Securities
</B>
<B>
</B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Our securities portfolio is the second largest component of earning assets and provides a
	significant source of revenue.&nbsp;&nbsp;Securities within the portfolio are classified as either held-to-maturity, available-for-sale
	or trading.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Held-to-maturity securities, which include any security for which management has the positive
	intent and ability to hold until maturity, are carried at historical cost, adjusted for amortization of premiums and accretion
	of discounts.&nbsp;&nbsp;Premiums and discounts are amortized and accreted, respectively, to interest income using the constant
	yield method over the period to maturity.&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest and dividends on investments in debt and equity securities are included
	in income when earned.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Available-for-sale securities, which include any security for which management has no immediate
	plans to sell, but which may be sold in the future, are carried at fair value.&nbsp;&nbsp;Realized gains and losses, based on amortized
	cost of the specific security, are included in other income.&nbsp;&nbsp;Unrealized gains and losses are recorded, net of related
	income tax effects, in stockholders' equity.&nbsp;&nbsp;Premiums and discounts are amortized and accreted, respectively, to interest
	income, using the constant yield method over the period to maturity.&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest and dividends on investments in debt and
	equity securities are included in income when earned.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Our philosophy regarding investments is conservative based on investment type and maturity.&nbsp;&nbsp;Investments
	in the portfolio primarily include U.S. Treasury securities, U.S. Government agencies, mortgage-backed securities and municipal
	securities.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our general policy is not to invest in derivative type investments or high-risk securities, except for collateralized
	mortgage-backed securities for which collection of principal and interest is not subordinated to significant superior rights held
	by others.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Held-to-maturity and available-for-sale investment securities were $705.4 million and $821.4
	million, respectively, at&nbsp;December 31, 2015, compared to the held-to-maturity amount of $777.6 million and available-for-sale
	amount of $305.3&nbsp;million at December 31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	As of December 31, 2015, $237.1 million, or 33.6%, of the held-to-maturity securities were
	invested in obligations of U.S. government agencies, 97.0% of which will mature in less than five years.&nbsp;&nbsp;In the available-for-sale
	securities, $124.2 million, or 15.1%, were in U.S. Treasury and U.S. government agency securities, 90.5% of which will mature in
	less than five years.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	In order to reduce our income tax burden, $440.1 million, or 62.5%, of the held-to-maturity
	securities portfolio, as of December 31, 2015, was invested in tax-exempt obligations of state and political subdivisions.&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	the available-for-sale securities, there was $9.9 million invested in tax-exempt obligations of state and political subdivisions.&nbsp;&nbsp;A
	significant portion of the state and political subdivision debt obligations are non-rated bonds and represent relatively small
	Arkansas, Kansas, Illinois, Missouri, Tennessee and Texas issues, which are evaluated on an ongoing basis.&nbsp;&nbsp;There are
	no securities of any one state or political subdivision issuer exceeding ten percent of our stockholders' equity at December 31,
	2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We had approximately $24.8 million, or 3.5% of the held-to-maturity portfolio invested in
	mortgaged-backed securities at December 31, 2015.&nbsp;&nbsp;In the available-for-sale securities, approximately $647.4 million,
	or 78.8% were invested in mortgaged-backed securities.&nbsp;&nbsp;Investments with limited marketability, such as stock in the
	Federal Reserve Bank and the Federal Home Loan Bank, are carried at cost and are reported as other available for sale securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	As of December 31, 2015, the held-to-maturity investment portfolio had gross unrealized gains
	of $9.8 million and gross unrealized losses of $1.8 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We had $350,000 of gross realized gains and $43,000 of realized losses from the sale of available
	for sale securities during the year ended December 31, 2015. We had $199,000 of gross realized gains and $191,000 of realized losses
	from the sale of available for sale securities during the year ended December 31, 2014. As part of the acquisition strategy related
	to Truman and Excel, we liquidated the acquired mortgage-backed securities, resulting in $193,000 of net realized losses during
	2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Trading securities, which include any security held primarily for near-term sale, are carried
	at fair value.&nbsp;&nbsp;Gains and losses on trading securities are included in other income.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our trading account is
	established and maintained for the benefit of investment banking.&nbsp;&nbsp;The trading account is typically used to provide inventory
	for resale and is not used to take advantage of short-term price movements.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 41; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	41
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage42"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Declines in the fair value of held-to-maturity and available-for-sale securities below their
	cost that are deemed to be other than temporary are reflected in earnings as realized losses.&nbsp;&nbsp;In estimating other-than-temporary
	impairment losses, management considers, among other things, (i) the length of time and the extent to which the fair value has
	been less than cost, (ii) the financial condition and near-term prospects of the issuer and (iii) the intent and ability of the
	Company to retain its investment in the issuer for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recovery in fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Management has the ability and intent to hold the securities classified as held to maturity
	until they mature, at which time we expect to receive full value for the securities. The contractual terms of those investments
	do not permit the issuer to settle the securities at a price less than the amortized cost bases of the investments.&nbsp;&nbsp;Furthermore,
	as of December 31, 2015, management also had the ability and intent to hold the securities classified as available-for-sale for
	a period of time sufficient for a recovery of cost.&nbsp;&nbsp;The unrealized losses are largely due to increases in market interest
	rates over the yields available at the time the underlying securities were purchased.&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value is expected to
	recover as the bonds approach their maturity date or repricing date or if market yields for such investments decline.&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
	does not believe any of the securities are impaired due to reasons of credit quality.&nbsp;&nbsp;Accordingly, as of December&nbsp;31,
	2015, management believes the impairments detailed in the table below are temporary.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Table 13 presents the carrying value and fair value of investment securities for each of
	the years indicated.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT">

	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Table 14 reflects the amortized cost and estimated fair value of securities at December 31,
	2015, by contractual maturity and the weighted average yields (for tax-exempt obligations on a fully taxable equivalent basis,
	assuming a 39.225% tax rate) of such securities.&nbsp;&nbsp;Expected maturities will differ from contractual maturities because
	borrowers may have the right to call or prepay obligations, with or without call or prepayment penalties.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; WIDTH: 100%">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 1PT SOLID">
<B>
<B>
	Deposits
</B>
<B>
</B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Deposits are our primary source of funding for earning assets and are primarily developed
	through our network of 149&nbsp;financial centers.&nbsp;&nbsp;We offer a variety of products designed to attract and retain customers
	with a continuing focus on developing core deposits.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our core deposits consist of all deposits excluding time deposits
	of $100,000 or more and brokered deposits.&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December 31, 2015, core deposits comprised 89.7% of our total deposits.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We continually monitor the funding requirements at each subsidiary bank along with competitive
	interest rates in the markets it serves.&nbsp;&nbsp;Because of our community banking philosophy, subsidiary bank executives in
	the local markets establish the interest rates offered on both core and non-core deposits.&nbsp;&nbsp;This approach ensures that
	the interest rates being paid are competitively priced for each particular deposit product and structured to meet the funding requirements.&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	believe we are paying a competitive rate when compared with pricing in those markets.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We manage our interest expense through deposit pricing and do not anticipate a significant
	change in total deposits. We believe that additional funds can be attracted and deposit growth can be accelerated through deposit
	pricing if it experiences increased loan demand or other liquidity needs.&nbsp;&nbsp;We also utilize brokered deposits as an additional
	source of funding to meet liquidity needs.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 43; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	43
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage44"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: RIGHT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Our total deposits as of December 31, 2015 were $6.086 billion, an increase of $2.225 billion,
	or 57.6%, from $3.861&nbsp;billion at December 31, 2014.&nbsp;&nbsp;The increase in deposits is due primarily to the First State
	and Liberty Bank acquisitions. We have also continued our strategy to move more volatile time deposits to less expensive, revenue
	enhancing transaction accounts throughout 2015.&nbsp;&nbsp;Non-interest bearing transaction accounts increased $391.0 million to
	$1.3&nbsp;billion at December 31, 2015, compared to $889.3 million at December 31, 2014.&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest bearing transaction
	and savings accounts were $3.486 billion at December 31, 2015, a $1.5 billion increase compared to $2.006&nbsp;billion on December
	31, 2014.&nbsp;&nbsp;Total time deposits increased approximately $354.8 million to $1.320&nbsp;billion at December 31, 2015, from
	$965.2&nbsp;million at December 31, 2014.&nbsp;&nbsp;In an attempt to utilize some of our excess liquidity, we have priced deposits
	in a manner to encourage a reduction in non-relationship time deposits.&nbsp;&nbsp;We had $1.4 million and $7.4 million of brokered
	deposits at December 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Table 15 reflects the classification of the average deposits and the average rate paid on
	each deposit category which is in excess of 10 percent of average total deposits for the three years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT">

<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 55PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">

	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; WIDTH: 100%">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 1PT SOLID">
<B>
<B>
	Fed Funds Purchased and Securities Sold under Agreements to Repurchase
</B>
<B>
</B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Federal funds purchased and securities sold under agreements to repurchase were $99.4 million
	at December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2015, as compared to $110.6 million at December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We have historically funded our growth in earning assets through the use of core deposits,
	large certificates of deposits from local markets, FHLB borrowings and Federal funds purchased.&nbsp;&nbsp;Management anticipates
	that these sources will provide necessary funding in the foreseeable future.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 44; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">

	44
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>

<A NAME="eolPage45"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; WIDTH: 100%">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 1PT SOLID">
<B>
<B>
	Other Borrowings and Subordinated Debentures
</B>
<B>
</B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Our total debt was $222.9 million and $135.3 million at December 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	outstanding balance for December 31, 2015 includes $40.0 million in FHLB short-term advances.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The outstanding long-term debt balance for December 31, 2015 includes $70.0&nbsp;million
	in&nbsp;FHLB long-term advances, $52.3 million in notes payable and $60.6&nbsp;million of trust preferred securities.&nbsp; The
	outstanding long-term debt balance for December 31, 2014 includes $71.6&nbsp;million in&nbsp;FHLB long-term advances, $43.1 million
	in notes payable and $20.6&nbsp;million of trust preferred securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	During October 2015, we borrowed $52.3 million from correspondent banks at a rate of 3.85%
	with quarterly principal and interest payments. The debt has a 10 year amortization with a 5 year balloon payment due in October
	2020. We used $36 million of this borrowing to refinance the debt issued during the fourth quarter of 2013.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The additional increase in debt was a result of our Community First and Liberty acquisitions
	and the assumption of the debt from those entities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Aggregate annual maturities of debt at December 31, 2015 are presented in table 17.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT">

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; WIDTH: 100%">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 1PT SOLID">
<B>
<B>
	Capital
</B>
<B>
</B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Overview
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	At December 31, 2015, total capital reached $1.077 billion.&nbsp;&nbsp;Capital represents
	shareholder ownership in the Company &#8211; the book value of assets in excess of liabilities.&nbsp;&nbsp;At December 31, 2015,
	our common equity to asset ratio was 13.8% compared to 10.6% at year-end 2014. The increase is primarily a result of increased
	earnings, organic and from the Community First, Liberty and Ozark Trust acquisitions.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Capital Stock
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	On February 27, 2009, at a special meeting, our shareholders approved an amendment to the
	Articles of Incorporation to establish 40,040,000 authorized shares of preferred stock, $0.01 par value.&nbsp;&nbsp;The aggregate
	liquidation preference of all shares of preferred stock cannot exceed $80,000,000.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	On February 27, 2015, as part of the acquisition of Community First, the Company issued 30,852
	shares of Senior Non-Cumulative Perpetual Preferred Stock, Series A (&#8220;Simmons Series A Preferred Stock&#8221;) in exchange
	for the outstanding shares of Community First Senior Non-Cumulative Perpetual Preferred Stock, Series C (&#8220;Community First
	Series C Preferred Stock&#8221;). The preferred stock is held by the United States Department of the Treasury (&#8220;Treasury&#8221;)
	as the Community First Series C Preferred Stock was issued when Community First entered into a Small Business Lending Fund Securities
	Purchase Agreement with the Treasury.&nbsp; The Simmons Series A Preferred Stock qualifies as Tier 1 capital and will pay quarterly
	dividends.&nbsp; The rate will remain fixed at 1% through February 18, 2016, at which time it will convert to a fixed rate of 9%.
	On January 29, 2016, the Company redeemed all of the Simmons Series A Preferred Stock, including accrued and unpaid dividends.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 45; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	45
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage46"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	On March 4, 2014 the Company filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and
	Exchange Commission (&ldquo;SEC&rdquo;).&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequently, on June 18, 2014, we filed Amendment No. 1 to the shelf registration
	statement. When declared effective, the shelf registration statement will allow us to raise capital from time to time, up to an
	aggregate of $300&nbsp;million, through the sale of common stock, preferred stock, stock warrants, stock rights or a combination
	thereof, subject to market conditions.&nbsp;&nbsp;Specific terms and prices are determined at the time of any offering under a
	separate prospectus supplement that the Company is required to file with the SEC at the time of the specific offering.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Stock Repurchase
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	During 2007, the Company approved a stock repurchase program which authorized the repurchase
	of up to 700,000 shares of common stock.&nbsp;&nbsp;On July 23, 2012, we announced the substantial completion of the existing stock
	repurchase program and the adoption by our Board of Directors of a new stock repurchase program.&nbsp;&nbsp;The current program
	authorizes the repurchase of up to 850,000 additional shares of Class A common stock, or approximately 5% of the shares outstanding.
	The shares are to be purchased from time to time at prevailing market prices, through open market or unsolicited negotiated transactions,
	depending upon market conditions.&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the repurchase program, there is no time limit for the stock repurchases, nor
	is there a minimum number of shares that we intend to repurchase.&nbsp;&nbsp;We may discontinue purchases at any time that management
	determines additional purchases are not warranted.&nbsp;&nbsp;We intend to use the repurchased shares to satisfy stock option exercises,
	payment of future stock awards and dividends and general corporate purposes.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We had no stock repurchases during 2014 or 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Cash Dividends
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We declared cash dividends on our common stock of $0.92 per share for the twelve months ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $0.88 per share for the twelve months ended December 31, 2014.&nbsp;&nbsp;The timing and amount
	of future dividends are at the discretion of our Board of Directors and will depend upon our consolidated earnings, financial condition,
	liquidity and capital requirements, the amount of cash dividends paid to us by our subsidiaries, applicable government regulations
	and policies and other factors considered relevant by our Board of Directors. Our Board of Directors anticipates that we will continue
	to pay quarterly dividends in amounts determined based on the factors discussed above.&nbsp;&nbsp;However, there can be no assurance
	that we will continue to pay dividends on our common stock at the current levels or at all.&nbsp;&nbsp;See Item 5, Market for Registrant&#8217;s
	Common Equity and Related Stockholder Matters, for additional information regarding cash dividends.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Parent Company Liquidity
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The primary liquidity needs of the Parent Company are the payment of dividends to shareholders
	and the funding of debt obligations.&nbsp;&nbsp;The primary sources for meeting these liquidity needs are the current cash on hand
	at the parent company and the future dividends received from subsidiary banks.&nbsp;&nbsp;Payment of dividends by the subsidiary
	banks is subject to various regulatory limitations.&nbsp;&nbsp;See Item 7A, Liquidity and Qualitative Disclosures About Market
	Risk, for additional information regarding the parent company&#8217;s liquidity.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Risk-Based Capital
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Our subsidiaries are subject to various regulatory capital requirements administered by the
	federal banking agencies. Failure to meet minimum capital requirements can initiate certain mandatory and possibly additional discretionary
	actions by regulators that, if undertaken, could have a direct material effect on our financial statements.&nbsp;&nbsp;Under capital
	adequacy guidelines and the regulatory framework for prompt corrective action, we must meet specific capital guidelines that involve
	quantitative measures of our assets, liabilities and certain off-balance-sheet items as calculated under regulatory accounting
	practices.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our capital amounts and classifications are also subject to qualitative judgments by the regulators about
	components, risk weightings and other factors.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Quantitative measures established by regulation to ensure capital adequacy require us to
	maintain minimum amounts and ratios (set forth in the table below) of total, Tier 1 and common equity Tier 1 capital (as defined
	in the regulations) to risk-weighted assets (as defined) and of Tier 1 capital (as defined) to average assets (as defined).&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
	believes that, as of December 31, 2015, we meet all capital adequacy requirements to which we are subject.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	As of the most recent notification from regulatory agencies, the subsidiaries were well capitalized
	under the regulatory framework for prompt corrective action.&nbsp;&nbsp;To be categorized as well capitalized, the Company and
	subsidiaries must maintain minimum total risk-based, Tier 1 risk-based, common equity Tier 1 risk-based and Tier 1 leverage ratios
	as set forth in the table.&nbsp;&nbsp;There are no conditions or events since that notification that management believes have changed
	the institutions&#8217; categories.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Regulatory Capital Changes
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	In July 2013, the Company&#8217;s primary federal regulator, the Federal Reserve, published
	final rules (the &#8220;Basel III Capital Rules&#8221;) establishing a new comprehensive capital framework for U.S. banks. The
	rules implement the Basel Committee&#8217;s December 2010 framework known as &#8220;Basel III&#8221; for strengthening international
	capital standards. The Basel III Capital Rules substantially revise the risk-based capital requirements applicable to bank holding
	companies and depository institutions compared to the current U.S. risk-based capital rules.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Basel III Capital Rules define the components of capital and address other issues affecting
	the numerator in banking institutions&#8217; regulatory capital ratios. The rules also address risk weights and other issues affecting
	the denominator in banking institutions&#8217; regulatory capital ratios and replace the existing risk-weighting approach with
	a more risk-sensitive approach.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Basel III Capital Rules expand the risk-weighting categories from the current four Basel
	I-derived categories (0%, 20%, 50% and 100%) to a much larger and more risk-sensitive number of categories, depending on the nature
	of the assets, generally ranging from 0% for U.S. government and agency securities, to 600% for certain equity exposures, and resulting
	in higher risk weights for a variety of asset categories, including many residential mortgages and certain commercial real estate.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 47; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	47
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage48"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The final rules include a new common equity Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted assets ratio
	of 4.5% and a common equity Tier&nbsp;1 capital conservation buffer of 2.5% of risk-weighted assets. The rules also raise the minimum
	ratio of Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted assets from 4.0% to 6.0% and require a minimum leverage ratio of 4.0%. The Basel III Capital
	Rules became effective for the Company and its subsidiary bank on January 1, 2015, with full compliance with all of the final rule&#8217;s
	requirements phased in over a multi-year schedule. Management believes that, as of December 31, 2015, the Company and Simmons Bank
	would meet all capital adequacy requirements under the Basel III Capital Rules on a fully phased-in basis if such requirements
	were currently effective.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; WIDTH: 100%">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 1PT SOLID">
<B>
<B>
	Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements and Aggregate Contractual Obligations
</B>
<B>
</B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	In the normal course of business, the Company enters into a number of financial commitments.&nbsp;&nbsp;Examples
	of these commitments include but are not limited to long-term debt financing, operating lease obligations, unfunded loan commitments
	and letters of credit.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Our long-term debt at December 31, 2015, includes notes payable, FHLB long-term advances
	and trust preferred securities, all of which we are contractually obligated to repay in future periods.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Operating lease obligations entered into by the Company are generally associated with the
	operation of a few of our financial centers located throughout the states of Arkansas, Kansas, Missouri and Tennessee.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	financial obligation on these locations is considered immaterial due to the limited number of financial centers that operate under
	an agreement of this type.&nbsp;&nbsp;Historically, we have purchased all of our automated teller machines (&#8220;ATMs&#8221;)
	and depreciated them over their estimated lives.&nbsp;&nbsp;In December 2012, we entered into a five-year operating lease agreement
	with our service provider to replace and maintain all outdated ATMs and the related operating software.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Commitments to extend credit and letters of credit are legally binding, conditional agreements
	generally having fixed expiration or termination dates.&nbsp;&nbsp;These commitments generally require customers to maintain certain
	credit standards and are established based on management&#8217;s credit assessment of the customer.&nbsp;&nbsp;The commitments
	may expire without being drawn upon.&nbsp;&nbsp;Therefore, the total commitment does not necessarily represent future funding requirements.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The funding requirements of the Company's most significant financial commitments at December
	31, 2015 are shown in table 19.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 55PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<B>
	Table 19:
</B>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 5PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<B>

	Funding Requirements of Financial Commitments
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; WIDTH: 100%">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 1PT SOLID">
<B>
<B>
	Reconciliation of Non-GAAP Measures
</B>
<B>
</B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We have $380.9 million and $130.6 million total goodwill and other intangible assets for
	the periods ended December 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014, respectively.&nbsp;&nbsp;Because of our high level of intangible assets,
	management believes a useful calculation is return on tangible equity (non-GAAP).&nbsp;&nbsp;This non-GAAP calculation for the
	twelve months ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014, 2013, 2012 and 2011, which is similar to the GAAP calculation of return on average
	stockholders&#8217; equity, is presented in table 20.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT">

</B>
</TD>

	&nbsp;

<!-- FIELD: RULE-PAGE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 3PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 1PT; BORDER-TOP: BLACK 1PT SOLID; WIDTH: 100%">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /RULE-PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The table below presents computations of core earnings (net income excluding nonrecurring
	items {gain from the sale of MasterCard stock and merchant services, gains on FDIC-assisted transactions and the related merger
	costs, liquidation gains and losses from FDIC-assisted transactions and traditional acquisitions, merger related costs, change-in-control
	payments, charter consolidation costs and the one-time costs of branch right sizing}) and diluted core earnings per share (non-GAAP).&nbsp;&nbsp;Nonrecurring
	items are included in financial results presented in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP).
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We believe the exclusion of these nonrecurring items in expressing earnings and certain other
	financial measures, including &#8220;core earnings,&#8221; provides a meaningful base for period-to-period and company-to-company
	comparisons, which management believes will assist investors and analysts in analyzing the core financial measures of the Company
	and predicting future performance. This non-GAAP financial measure is also used by management to assess the performance of the
	Company&#8217;s business because management does not consider these nonrecurring items to be relevant to ongoing financial performance.&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
	and the Board of Directors utilize &#8220;core earnings&#8221; (non-GAAP) for the following purposes:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 0 0.5IN">
	&#8226;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Preparation of the Company&#8217;s operating budgets
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 0 0.5IN">
	&#8226;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Monthly financial performance reporting
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 0 0.5IN">
	&#8226;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Monthly &#8220;flash&#8221; reporting of consolidated results
	(management only)
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 0 0.5IN">
	&#8226;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investor presentations of Company performance
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We believe the presentation of &#8220;core earnings&#8221; on a diluted per share basis,
	&#8220;diluted core earnings per share&#8221; (non-GAAP), provides a meaningful base for period-to-period and company-to-company
	comparisons, which management believes will assist investors and analysts in analyzing the core financial measures of the Company
	and predicting future performance. This non-GAAP financial measure is also used by management to assess the performance of the
	Company&#8217;s business, because management does not consider these nonrecurring items to be relevant to ongoing financial performance
	on a per share basis.&nbsp;&nbsp;Management and the Board of Directors utilize &#8220;diluted core earnings per share&#8221; (non-GAAP)
	for the following purposes:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 0 0.5IN">
	&#8226;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Calculation of annual performance-based incentives for
	certain executives
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 0 0.5IN">
	&#8226;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investor presentations of Company performance
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We believe that presenting these non-GAAP financial measures will permit investors and analysts
	to assess the performance of the Company on the same basis as that applied by management and the Board of Directors.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 49; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	49
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage50"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&#8220;Core earnings&#8221; and &#8220;diluted core earnings per share&#8221; (non-GAAP)
	have inherent limitations and are not required to be uniformly applied and are not audited.&nbsp;&nbsp;To mitigate these limitations,
	we have procedures in place to identify and approve each item that qualifies as nonrecurring to ensure that the Company&#8217;s
	&#8220;core&#8221; results are properly reflected for period-to-period comparisons.&nbsp;&nbsp;Although these non-GAAP financial
	measures are frequently used by stakeholders in the evaluation of a company, they have limitations as analytical tools and should
	not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analyses of results as reported under GAAP.&nbsp;&nbsp;In particular, a measure
	of earnings that excludes nonrecurring items does not represent the amount that effectively accrues directly to stockholders&nbsp;(i.e.,
	nonrecurring items are included in earnings and stockholders&#8217; equity).
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	During 2015, we recorded after-tax merger related costs of $8.4 million, primarily related
	to the Community First, Liberty and Ozark Trust acquisitions, resulting in a nonrecurring charge of $0.30 to diluted earnings
	per share. During the second quarter of 2015 we incurred $1.9 million in after-tax branch right sizing costs in relation to the
	closure of twelve underperforming branches, resulting in a nonrecurring charge of $0.07 to diluted earnings per share. Also during
	2015, we recognized $1.3 million in net after-tax gains from the sale of our Salina banking operations contributing $0.04 to diluted
	earnings per share.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	During the third quarter of 2015, we entered terminated the loss-share agreements with the
	FDIC and incurred $4.5 million after tax one-time charge expense which resulted in a decrease of $0.16 to diluted earnings per
	share. We incurred after-tax costs of $1.3 for early termination agreement during the year, resulting in a nonrecurring charge
	of $0.05 to diluted earnings per share.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	During 2014, we recorded after-tax merger related costs of
	$4.5 million, primarily related to the Delta Trust acquisition, resulting in a nonrecurring charge of $0.27 to diluted earnings
	per share. During the first quarter of 2014, we closed eleven legacy Simmons Bank branches as part of the initial branch right
	sizing strategy of the Metropolitan acquisition. Our total after-tax cost of branch right sizing was $2.9 million in 2014, resulting
	in a nonrecurring charge of $0.17 to diluted earnings per share.
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Also during 2014 we recognized
	$4.7 million in net after-tax gains from the sale of former branch locations, primarily the legacy Simmons Bank and acquired Metropolitan
	closures, contributing $0.27 to diluted earnings per share.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	During the second quarter of 2014, we recorded an after-tax gain of $608,000 from the sale
	of our merchant services business, contributing $0.04 to diluted earnings per share. We incurred after-tax costs of $396,000 and
	$538,000, respectively, for charter consolidations and change-in-control payments during the year, resulting in a nonrecurring
	charge of $0.05 to diluted earnings per share.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	During the third and fourth quarter of 2013, we recorded after-tax
	merger related costs of $3.9 million related to the Metropolitan acquisition, resulting in a nonrecurring charge of $0.25 to diluted
	earnings per share. During the third and fourth quarters, we closed seven underperforming branches at a cost of $390,000 after-tax,
	resulting in a nonrecurring charge of $0.02 to diluted earnings per share.
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	Also, as part
	of our 2012 acquisition strategy, we sold many of the investment securities from Excel and Truman, resulting in an after- tax loss
	of $117,000.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	During the third quarter of 2012, we recorded an after-tax bargain purchase gain of $681,000
	on the FDIC-assisted acquisition of Truman, along with merger related costs of $495,000, after tax.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;These nonrecurring
	items related to Truman contributed $0.01 to diluted earnings per share.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	During the fourth quarter of 2012, we recorded an after-tax bargain purchase gain of $1.4
	million on the FDIC-assisted acquisition of Excel, along with merger related costs of $657,000, after tax.&nbsp;&nbsp;Also, as
	part of our acquisition strategy, FHLB advances were paid off resulting in a $106,000 pre-payment expense, after tax.&nbsp;&nbsp;These
	nonrecurring items related to Excel contributed $0.04 to diluted earnings per share.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	During the second quarter of 2011, we recorded an after-tax gain of $688,000 on the sale
	of MasterCard stock, contributing $0.04 to diluted earnings per share.&nbsp;&nbsp;Also during the second quarter, as a result of
	our right sizing initiative, we recorded a nonrecurring charge of $0.01 to diluted earnings per share.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	During the first and second quarters of 2011, we recorded after-tax merger related costs
	of $217,000 on the FDIC-assisted acquisition of Security Savings Bank in Olathe, Kansas (&#8220;SSB&#8221;), resulting in a nonrecurring
	charge of $0.01 to diluted earnings per share.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
</P>

<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT; TEXT-INDENT: 20PT">
	Loss on FDIC loss-share termination
</TD>
<TD STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;

	&nbsp;
</DIV>
