<!-- FIELD: /RULE-PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 15PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	(1)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 5PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	EPS
	are computed independently for each quarter and therefore the sum of each quarterly EPS
	may not equal the year-to-date EPS. As a result of the large stock issuances during 2015
	as part of the Company&#8217;s acquisitions, the computed independent quarterly average
	common shares outstanding and the computed year-to-date average common shares differ
	significantly. The difference is based on the direct result of the varying denominator
	for each period presented.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-INDENT: -1IN; MARGIN: 0 0 0 1IN">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</P>
<EFX_MARKET_RISK>
<A NAME="FIS_MARKET_RISK"></A>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 55PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 11PT">
<B>
<A NAME="F10K_022916P_HTM_A_011">
</A>
	ITEM 7A.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 5PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 11PT">
<B>
	QUANTITATIVE
	AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; FONT: 10PT TIMES NEW ROMAN, TIMES, SERIF; WIDTH: 100%">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 1PT SOLID">
<B>
<B>
	Liquidity and Market Risk Management
</B>
<B>
</B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Parent Company
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company has leveraged its investment in Simmons Bank, its subsidiary bank, and depends
	upon the dividends paid to it, as the sole shareholder of the subsidiary bank, as a principal source of funds for dividends to
	shareholders, stock repurchases and debt service requirements.&nbsp;&nbsp;At December 31, 2015, undivided profits of Simmons Bank
	were approximately $228.7 million, of which approximately $8.2 million was available for the payment of dividends to the Company
	without regulatory approval.&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to dividends, other sources of liquidity for the Company are the sale of equity
	securities and the borrowing of funds.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Subsidiary Bank
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Generally speaking, the Company's subsidiary bank, Simmons Bank, relies upon net inflows
	of cash from financing activities, supplemented by net inflows of cash from operating activities, to provide cash used in investing
	activities.&nbsp;&nbsp;Typical of most banking companies, significant financing activities include: deposit gathering; use of short-term
	borrowing facilities, such as federal funds purchased and repurchase agreements; and the issuance of long-term debt.&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	subsidiary bank&#8217;s primary investing activities include loan originations and purchases of investment securities, offset by
	loan payoffs and investment maturities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Liquidity represents an institution's ability to provide funds to satisfy demands from depositors
	and borrowers by either converting assets into cash or accessing new or existing sources of incremental funds.&nbsp;&nbsp;A major
	responsibility of management is to maximize net interest income within prudent liquidity constraints.&nbsp;&nbsp;Internal corporate
	guidelines have been established to constantly measure liquid assets as well as relevant ratios concerning earning asset levels
	and purchased funds.&nbsp;&nbsp;The management and board of directors of the subsidiary bank monitor these same indicators and
	make adjustments as needed. At December 31, 2015, Simmons Bank and total corporate liquidity remains strong.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 52; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	52
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage53"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Liquidity Management
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The objective of our liquidity management is to access adequate sources of funding to ensure
	that cash flow requirements of depositors and borrowers are met in an orderly and timely manner.&nbsp;&nbsp;Sources of liquidity
	are managed so that reliance on any one funding source is kept to a minimum.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our liquidity sources are prioritized for
	both availability and time to activation.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Our liquidity is a primary consideration in determining funding needs and is an integral
	part of asset/liability management. Pricing of the liability side is a major component of interest margin and spread management.&nbsp;&nbsp;Adequate
	liquidity is a necessity in addressing this critical task.&nbsp;&nbsp;There are five primary and secondary sources of liquidity
	available to the Company.&nbsp;&nbsp;The particular liquidity need and timeframe determine the use of these sources.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The first source of liquidity available to the Company is Federal funds.&nbsp;&nbsp;Federal
	funds, primarily from downstream correspondent banks, are available on a daily basis and are used to meet the normal fluctuations
	of a dynamic balance sheet.&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, the Company and the Bank have approximately $230 million in Federal funds lines
	of credit from upstream correspondent banks that can be accessed, when needed.&nbsp;&nbsp;In order to ensure availability of these
	upstream funds we test these borrowing lines at least annually.&nbsp;&nbsp;Historical monitoring of these funds has made it possible
	for us to project seasonal fluctuations and structure our funding requirements on a month-to-month basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	A second source of liquidity is the retail deposits available through our network of financial
	centers throughout Arkansas, Kansas, Missouri and Tennessee. Although this method can be a somewhat more expensive alternative
	to supplying liquidity, this source can be used to meet intermediate term liquidity needs.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Third, Simmons Bank has lines of credits available with the Federal Home Loan Bank.&nbsp;&nbsp;While
	we use portions of those lines to match off longer-term mortgage loans, we also use those lines to meet liquidity needs.&nbsp;&nbsp;Approximately
	$965&nbsp;million of these lines of credit are currently available, if needed.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Fourth, we use a laddered investment portfolio that ensures there is a steady source of intermediate
	term liquidity.&nbsp;&nbsp;These funds can be used to meet seasonal loan patterns and other intermediate term balance sheet fluctuations.&nbsp;&nbsp;Approximately
	54% of the investment portfolio is classified as available-for-sale.&nbsp;&nbsp;We also use securities held in the securities portfolio
	to pledge when obtaining public funds.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Fifth, we have a network of correspondent banks from which we can access debt to meet liquidity
	needs, as was demonstrated by the $52.3 million of unsecured debt issued in the fourth quarter of 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Finally, we have the ability to access large deposits from both the public and private sector
	to fund short-term liquidity needs.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We believe the various sources available are ample liquidity to satisfy our current short-term,
	intermediate-term and long-term operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Market Risk Management
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Market risk arises from changes in interest rates.&nbsp;&nbsp;We have risk management policies
	to monitor and limit exposure to market risk.&nbsp;&nbsp;In asset and liability management activities, policies designed to minimize
	structural interest rate risk are in place.&nbsp;&nbsp;The measurement of market risk associated with financial instruments is
	meaningful only when all related and offsetting on- and off-balance-sheet transactions are aggregated, and the resulting net positions
	are identified.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 53; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	53
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage54"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Interest Rate Sensitivity
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Interest rate risk represents the potential impact of interest rate changes on net income
	and capital resulting from mismatches in repricing opportunities of assets and liabilities over a period of time. A number of tools
	are used to monitor and manage interest rate risk, including simulation models and interest sensitivity gap analysis. Management
	uses simulation models to estimate the effects of changing interest rates and various balance sheet strategies on the level of
	the Company&#8217;s net income and capital. As a means of limiting interest rate risk to an acceptable level, management may alter
	the mix of floating and fixed-rate assets and liabilities, change pricing schedules and manage investment maturities during future
	security purchases.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The simulation model incorporates management&#8217;s assumptions regarding the level of interest
	rates or balance changes for indeterminate maturity deposits for a given level of market rate changes. These assumptions have been
	developed through anticipated pricing behavior. Key assumptions in the simulation models include the relative timing of prepayments,
	cash flows and maturities. These assumptions are inherently uncertain and, as a result, the model cannot precisely estimate net
	interest income or precisely predict the impact of a change in interest rates on net income or capital. Actual results will differ
	from simulated results due to the timing, magnitude and frequency of interest rate changes and changes in market conditions and
	management strategies, among other factors.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	As of December 31, 2015, the model simulations projected that 100 and 200 basis point increases
	in interest rates would result in negative variance in net interest income of -0.52% and -0.98%, respectively, relative to the
	base case over the next 12 months, while decreases in interest rates of 100 basis points would result in a negative variance in
	net interest income of -0.44% relative to the base case over the next 12 months. The likelihood of a decrease in interest rates
	in excess of 50&nbsp;basis points as of December 31, 2015 is considered remote given current interest rate levels and recent rate
	increase by the Federal Reserve. These are good faith estimates and assume that the composition of our interest sensitive assets
	and liabilities existing at each year-end will remain constant over the relevant twelve month measurement period and that changes
	in market interest rates are instantaneous and sustained across the yield curve regardless of duration of pricing characteristics
	of specific assets or liabilities. Also, this analysis does not contemplate any actions that we might undertake in response to
	changes in market interest rates. We believe these estimates are not necessarily indicative of what actually could occur in the
	event of immediate interest rate increases or decreases of this magnitude. As interest-bearing assets and liabilities reprice in
	different time frames and proportions to market interest rate movements, various assumptions must be made based on historical relationships
	of these variables in reaching any conclusion. Since these correlations are based on competitive and market conditions, we anticipate
	that our future results will likely be different from the foregoing estimates, and such differences could be material.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The table below presents our sensitivity to net interest income at December 31, 2015.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 55PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<B>
	Table 23:
</B>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 5PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<B>
</B>
<B>
	Net Interest Income Sensitivity
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 54; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">

<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
<A NAME="F10K_022916P_HTM_A_013">
</A>
	Management&#8217;s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The management of Simmons First National Corporation (the &#8220;Company&#8221;) is responsible
	for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting. The Company&#8217;s internal control over
	financial reporting is a process designed under the supervision of the Company&#8217;s Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial
	Officer to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of the Company&#8217;s
	financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	As of December 31, 2015, management assessed the effectiveness of the Company&#8217;s internal
	control over financial reporting based on the criteria for effective internal control over financial reporting established in
<I>
	Internal
	Control - Integrated Framework (2013 edition) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO)
</I>
	.&nbsp;&nbsp;
	Based on this assessment, management determined that the Company maintained effective internal control over financial reporting
	as of December 31, 2015, based on the specified criteria.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	BKD, LLP, the independent registered public accounting firm that audited the consolidated
	financial statements of the Company included in this Annual Report on Form 10-K, has issued an attestation report on the effectiveness
	of the Company&#8217;s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015.&nbsp;&nbsp;The report, which expresses
	an unqualified opinion on the effectiveness of the Company&#8217;s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31,
	2015, immediately follows.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: RIGHT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 56; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	56
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage57"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<EFX_AUDITORS_OPINION>
<A NAME="FIS_AUDITORS_OPINION"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
<A NAME="F10K_022916P_HTM_A_014">
</A>
	REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Audit Committee, Board of Directors and Stockholders
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Simmons First National Corporation
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Pine Bluff, Arkansas
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We have audited Simmons First National Corporation&#8217;s internal control over financial
	reporting as of December 31, 2015, based on criteria established in
<I>
	Internal Control-Integrated Framework (2013 edition) issued
	by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO)
</I>
	.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#8217;s management is
	responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of
	internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying
<I>
	Management&#8217;s Report on Internal Control over Financial
	Reporting
</I>
	.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company&#8217;s internal control over financial reporting
	based on our audit.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting
	Oversight Board (United States).&nbsp;&nbsp;Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance
	about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our audit
	included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists
	and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	audit also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe that
	our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	A company&#8217;s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide
	reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external
	purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.&nbsp;&nbsp;A company&#8217;s internal control over financial
	reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately
	and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions
	are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles,
	and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors
	of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use
	or disposition of the company&#8217;s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent
	or detect misstatements.&nbsp;&nbsp;Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk
	that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures
	may deteriorate.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	In our opinion, Simmons First National Corporation maintained, in all material respects,
	effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015, based on criteria established in
<I>
	Internal Control-Integrated
	Framework (2013 edition) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO).
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We have also audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight
	Board (United States), the consolidated financial statements of Simmons First National Corporation and our report dated February
	29, 2016, expressed an unqualified opinion thereon.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 58%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 42%">
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	BKD,&nbsp;LLP
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	/s/ BKD, LLP
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Little Rock, Arkansas
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	February 29, 2016
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: RIGHT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">

<EFX_AUDITORS_OPINION>
<A NAME="FIS_AUDITORS_OPINION_2"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
<A NAME="F10K_022916P_HTM_A_015">
</A>
	REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Audit Committee, Board of Directors and Stockholders
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Simmons First National Corporation
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Pine Bluff, Arkansas
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Simmons First National Corporation
	as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, and 2014, and the related consolidated statements of income, comprehensive income, cash flows and
	stockholders&#8217; equity for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2015.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#8217;s
	management is responsible for these financial statements. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements
	based on our audits.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting
	Oversight Board (United States).&nbsp;&nbsp;Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance
	about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our audits included examining, on a test basis,
	evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant
	estimates made by management and evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe that our audits
	provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in
	all material respects, the financial position of Simmons First National Corporation as of December 31, 2015, and 2014, and the
	results of its operations and its cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2015, in conformity
	with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	We have also audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight
	Board (United States), Simmons First National Corporation&#8217;s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31,
	2015, based on criteria established in
<I>
	Internal Control-Integrated Framework (2013 edition) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring
	Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO)
</I>
	and our report dated February 29, 2016, expressed an&nbsp;unqualified opinion
	on the effectiveness of the Company&#8217;s internal control over financial reporting.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">

	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 50%">
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">

	BKD,&nbsp;LLP
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	/s/ BKD, LLP
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Little Rock, Arkansas
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	February 29, 2016

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN: 0">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 11PT">
<B>
	Simmons First National Corporation
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_NOTES_TO_FINANCIAL_STATEMENT>
<A NAME="FIS_NOTES_TO_FINANCIAL_STATEMENT"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER; MARGIN: 0">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 11PT">
<B>
<A NAME="F10K_022916P_HTM_A_021">
</A>
	Notes to Consolidated
	Financial Statements
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 55PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<B>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<DIV DATA-TD-STATEMENT-TYPE="NOTE">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 55PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<B>
	NOTE 1:
</B>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 5PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<B>
</B>
<B>
	SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: RULE-PAGE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 3PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 1PT; BORDER-TOP: BLACK 1PT SOLID; WIDTH: 100%">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /RULE-PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<U>
</U>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Nature of Operations and Principles of Consolidation
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Simmons First National Corporation (the &#8220;Company&#8221;) is primarily engaged in providing
	a full range of banking services to individual and corporate customers through its subsidiaries and their branch banks with offices
	in Arkansas, Kansas, Missouri and Tennessee.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is subject to competition from other financial institutions.&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	Company also is subject to the regulation of certain federal and state agencies and undergoes periodic examinations by those regulatory
	authorities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Simmons First National Corporation
	and its subsidiaries. Significant intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Operating Segments
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0PT 0">
	The Company is organized on a regional basis upon which management makes decisions regarding
	how to allocate resources and assess performance.&nbsp;&nbsp;Each of the regions provides a group of similar community banking
	services, including such products and services as loans; time deposits, checking and savings accounts; personal and corporate trust
	services; credit cards; investment management; insurance; and securities and investment services.&nbsp;Loan products include consumer,
	real estate, commercial, agricultural, equipment and SBA lending.&nbsp;The individual bank regions have similar operating and economic
	characteristics and have been reported as one aggregated operating segment.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0PT 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0PT 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company also considers its trust, investment and insurance services to be operating segments.
	Information on these segments is not reported separately since they do not meet the quantitative thresholds under ASC Topic 280-10-50-12.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0PT 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0PT 0">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Use of Estimates
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally
	accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts
	of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported
	amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.&nbsp;&nbsp;Actual results could differ from those estimates.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Material estimates that are particularly susceptible to significant change relate to the
	determination of the allowance for loan losses, the valuation of real estate acquired in connection with foreclosures or in satisfaction
	of loans and the valuation of covered loans and related indemnification asset.&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with the determination
	of the allowance for loan losses and the valuation of foreclosed assets, management obtains independent appraisals for significant
	properties.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Reclassifications
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Various items within the accompanying consolidated financial statements for previous years
	have been reclassified to provide more comparative information.&nbsp;&nbsp;These reclassifications had no effect on net earnings.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Cash Equivalents
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company considers all liquid investments with original maturities of three months or
	less to be cash equivalents.&nbsp;&nbsp;For purposes of the consolidated statements of cash flows, cash and cash equivalents are
	considered to include cash and non-interest bearing balances due from banks, interest bearing balances due from banks and federal
	funds sold and securities purchased under agreements to resell.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Investment Securities
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Held-to-maturity securities, which include any security for which the Company has the positive
	intent and ability to hold until maturity, are carried at historical cost adjusted for amortization of premiums and accretion of
	discounts.&nbsp;&nbsp;Premiums and discounts are amortized and accreted, respectively, to interest income using the constant yield
	method over the period to maturity.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Available-for-sale securities, which include any security for which the Company has no immediate
	plan to sell but which may be sold in the future, are carried at fair value.&nbsp;&nbsp;Realized gains and losses, based on specifically
	identified amortized cost of the individual security, are included in other income.&nbsp;&nbsp;Unrealized gains and losses are
	recorded, net of related income tax effects, in stockholders' equity.&nbsp;&nbsp;Premiums and discounts are amortized and accreted,
	respectively, to interest income using the constant yield method over the period to maturity.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 64; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	64
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage65"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Trading securities, which include any security held primarily for near-term sale, are carried
	at fair value.&nbsp;&nbsp;Gains&nbsp;and losses on trading securities are included in other income.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company applies accounting guidance related to recognition and presentation of other-than-temporary
	impairment under ASC Topic 320-10.&nbsp;&nbsp;When the Company does not intend to sell a debt security, and it is more likely than
	not, the Company will not have to sell the security before recovery of its cost basis, it recognizes the credit component of an
	other-than-temporary impairment of a debt security in earnings and the remaining portion in other comprehensive income.&nbsp;&nbsp;For
	held-to-maturity debt securities, the amount of an other-than-temporary impairment recorded in other comprehensive income for the
	noncredit portion of a previous other-than-temporary impairment is amortized prospectively over the remaining life of the security
	on the basis of the timing of future estimated cash flows of the security.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	As a result of this guidance, the Company&#8217;s consolidated statements of income reflect
	the full impairment (that is, the difference between the security&#8217;s amortized cost basis and fair value) on debt securities
	that the Company intends to sell or would more likely than not be required to sell before the expected recovery of the amortized
	cost basis.&nbsp;&nbsp;For available-for-sale and held-to-maturity debt securities that management has no intent to sell and believes
	that it more likely than not will not be required to sell prior to recovery, only the credit loss component of the impairment is
	recognized in earnings, while the noncredit loss is recognized in accumulated other comprehensive income.&nbsp;&nbsp;The credit
	loss component recognized in earnings is identified as the amount of principal cash flows not expected to be received over the
	remaining term of the security as projected based on cash flow projections.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Mortgage Loans Held For Sale
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Mortgage loans held for sale are carried at the lower of cost or fair value, determined using
	an aggregate basis. Write-downs to fair value are recognized as a charge to earnings at the time the decline in value occurs.&nbsp;&nbsp;Forward
	commitments to sell mortgage loans are acquired to reduce market risk on mortgage loans in the process of origination and mortgage
	loans held for sale.&nbsp;&nbsp;The forward commitments acquired by the Company for mortgage loans in process of origination are
	not mandatory forward commitments.&nbsp;&nbsp;These commitments are structured on a best efforts basis; therefore, the Company
	is not required to substitute another loan or to buy back the commitment if the original loan does not fund.&nbsp;&nbsp;Typically,
	the Company delivers the mortgage loans within a few days after the loans are funded.&nbsp;&nbsp;These commitments are derivative
	instruments and their fair values at December 31, 2015 and 2014 are not material.&nbsp;&nbsp;Gains and losses resulting from sales
	of mortgage loans are recognized when the respective loans are sold to investors.&nbsp;&nbsp;Gains and losses are determined by
	the difference between the selling price and the carrying amount of the loans sold, net of discounts collected or paid.&nbsp;&nbsp;Fees
	received from borrowers to guarantee the funding of mortgage loans held for sale are recognized as income or expense when the loans
	are sold or when it becomes evident that the commitment will not be used.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Loans
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Loans that management has the intent and ability to hold for the foreseeable future or until
	maturity or pay-offs are reported at their outstanding principal adjusted for any loans charged off, the allowance for loan losses
	and any unamortized deferred fees or costs on originated loans and unamortized premiums or discounts on purchased loans.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	For loans amortized at cost, interest income is accrued based on the unpaid principal balance.&nbsp;&nbsp;Loan
	origination fees, net of certain direct origination costs, as well as premiums and discounts, are deferred and amortized as a level
	yield adjustment over the respective term of the loan.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The accrual of interest on loans, except on certain government guaranteed loans, is discontinued
	at the time the loan is 90&nbsp;days past due unless the credit is well-secured and in process of collection.&nbsp;&nbsp;Past due
	status is based on contractual terms of the loan.&nbsp;&nbsp;In all cases, loans are placed on nonaccrual or charged off at an
	earlier date if collection of principal or interest is considered doubtful.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Discounts and premiums on purchased residential real estate loans are amortized to income
	using the interest method over the remaining period to contractual maturity, adjusted for anticipated prepayments.&nbsp;&nbsp;Discounts
	and premiums on purchased consumer loans are recognized over the expected lives of the loans using methods that approximate the
	interest method.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	For discussion of the Company&#8217;s accounting for acquired loans, see Acquisition Accounting,
	Covered Loans and Related Indemnification Asset later in this section.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 65; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	65
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage66"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Allowance for Loan Losses
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The allowance for loan losses is management&#8217;s estimate of probable losses in the loan
	portfolio.&nbsp;&nbsp;Loan losses are charged against the allowance when management believes the uncollectability of a loan balance
	is confirmed.&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequent recoveries, if any, are credited to the allowance.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Allocations to the allowance for loan losses are categorized as either general reserves or
	specific reserves.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The general reserve is calculated monthly based on management&#8217;s assessment of several
	factors such as (1) historical loss experience based on volumes and types, (2) volume and trends in delinquencies and nonaccruals,
	(3) lending policies and procedures including those for loan losses, collections and recoveries, (4) national, state and local
	economic trends and conditions, (5) concentrations of credit within the loan portfolio, (6) the experience, ability and depth of
	lending management and staff and (7) other factors and trends that will affect specific loans and categories of loans.&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	Company establishes general allocations for each major loan category and risk rating.&nbsp;&nbsp;This category also includes allocations
	to loans which are collectively evaluated for loss such as credit cards, one-to-four family owner occupied residential real estate
	loans and other consumer loans.&nbsp;&nbsp;General reserves have been established, based upon the aforementioned factors and allocated
	to the individual loan categories.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Specific reserves are provided on loans that are considered impaired when it is probable
	that we will not receive all amounts due according to the contractual terms of the loan, including scheduled principal and interest
	payments.&nbsp;&nbsp;This includes loans that are delinquent 90 days or more, nonaccrual loans and certain other loans identified
	by management. Certain other loans identified by management consist of performing loans where management expects that the Company
	will not receive all amounts due according to the contractual terms of the loan, including scheduled principal and interest payments.
	Specific reserves are accrued for probable losses on specific loans evaluated for impairment for which the basis of each loan,
	including accrued interest, exceeds the discounted amount of expected future collections of interest and principal or, alternatively,
	the fair value of loan collateral.&nbsp;&nbsp;Accrual of interest is discontinued and interest accrued and unpaid is removed at
	the time such amounts are delinquent 90 days unless management is aware of circumstances which warrant continuing the interest
	accrual.&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest is recognized for nonaccrual loans only upon receipt and only after all principal amounts are current
	according to the terms of the contract.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Management&#8217;s evaluation of the allowance for loan losses is inherently subjective as
	it requires material estimates.&nbsp;&nbsp;The actual amounts of loan losses realized in the near term could differ from the amounts
	estimated in arriving at the allowance for loan losses reported in the financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Reserve for Unfunded Commitments
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	In addition to the allowance for loan losses, the Company has established a reserve for unfunded
	commitments, classified in other liabilities.&nbsp;&nbsp;This reserve is maintained at a level sufficient to absorb losses arising
	from unfunded loan commitments. The adequacy of the reserve for unfunded commitments is determined monthly based on methodology
	similar to the Company&#8217;s methodology for determining the allowance for loan losses.&nbsp;&nbsp;Net adjustments to the reserve
	for unfunded commitments are included in other non-interest expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Acquisition Accounting, Acquired Loans
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company accounts for its acquisitions under ASC Topic 805,
<I>
	Business Combinations
</I>
	,
	which requires the use of the purchase method of accounting. All identifiable assets acquired, including loans, are recorded at
	fair value. No allowance for loan losses related to the acquired loans is recorded on the acquisition date as the fair value of
	the loans acquired incorporates assumptions regarding credit risk. Loans acquired are recorded at fair value in accordance with
	the fair value methodology prescribed in ASC Topic 820. The fair value estimates associated with the loans include estimates related
	to expected prepayments and the amount and timing of undiscounted expected principal, interest and other cash flows.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0PT 0">
	The Company evaluates loans acquired in accordance with the provisions of ASC Topic 310-20,
<I>
	Nonrefundable Fees and Other Costs
</I>
	. The fair value discount on these loans is accreted into interest income over the weighted
	average life of the loans using a constant yield method. These loans are not considered to be impaired loans. The Company evaluates
	purchased impaired loans in accordance with the provisions of ASC Topic 310-30,
<I>
	Loans and Debt Securities Acquired with Deteriorated
	Credit Quality
</I>
	. Purchased loans are considered impaired if there is evidence of credit deterioration since origination and
	if it is probable that not all contractually required payments will be collected.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0PT 0">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	For impaired loans accounted for under ASC Topic 310-30, the Company continues to estimate
	cash flows expected to be collected on these loans. The Company evaluates at each balance sheet date whether the present value
	of the loans determined using the effective interest rates has decreased significantly and if so, recognize a provision for loan
	loss in our consolidated statement of income. For any significant increases in cash flows expected to be collected, the Company
	adjusts the amount of accretable yield recognized on a prospective basis over the remaining life of the loan.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 66; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	66
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage67"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Covered Loans and Related Indemnification Asset
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	In September, we entered into an agreement with the FDIC to terminate all loss share agreements
	which were entered into in 2010 and 2012 in conjunction with the Company&#8217;s acquisition of substantially all of the assets
	(&#8220;covered assets&#8221;) and assumption of substantially all of the liabilities of four failed banks in FDIC-assisted transactions.
	Under the early termination, all rights and obligations of the Company and the FDIC under the FDIC loss share agreements, including
	the clawback provisions and the settlement of loss share and expense reimbursement claims, have been resolved and terminated.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Under the terms of the agreement, the FDIC made a net payment of $2,368,000 to the bank
	as consideration for the early termination of the loss share agreements. The early termination was recorded in the Company&#8217;s
	financial statements by removing the FDIC Indemnification Asset, receivable from FDIC, the FDIC True-up liability and recording
	a one-time, pre-tax charge of $7,476,000. As a result, the Company reclassified loans previously covered by FDIC loss share to
	loans acquired, not covered by FDIC loss share. Foreclosed assets previously covered by FDIC loss share were reclassified to foreclosed
	assets not covered by FDIC loss share.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	For further discussion of our acquisition and loan accounting, see Note 2, Acquisitions,
	and Note 5, Loans Acquired.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Premises and Equipment
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Depreciable assets are stated at cost less accumulated depreciation.&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation
	is charged to expense using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets.&nbsp;&nbsp;Leasehold improvements
	are capitalized and amortized by the straight-line method over the terms of the respective leases or the estimated useful lives
	of the improvements, whichever is shorter.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Premises Held for Sale
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company records premises held for sale at the lower of (1) cost less accumulated depreciation
	or (2) fair value less estimated selling expenses. These assets are assessed for impairment at the time they are reclassified as
	held for sale and periodically thereafter.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
<B>
	Foreclosed Assets Held For Sale
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Assets acquired by foreclosure or in settlement of debt and held for sale are valued at estimated
	fair value as of the date of foreclosure, and a related valuation allowance is provided for estimated costs to sell the assets.&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
	evaluates the value of foreclosed assets held for sale periodically and increases the valuation allowance for any subsequent declines
	in fair value.&nbsp;&nbsp;Changes in the valuation allowance are charged or credited to other expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
<B>
	Bank Owned Life Insurance
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company maintains bank-owned life insurance policies on certain current and former employees
	and directors, which are recorded at their cash surrender values as determined by the insurance carriers. The appreciation in the
	cash surrender value of the policies is recognized as a component of non-interest income in the Company&#8217;s consolidated statements
	of income.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Goodwill and Intangible Assets
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0PT 0">
	Goodwill represents the excess of the cost of an acquisition over the fair value of the
	net assets acquired.&nbsp;&nbsp;Other intangible assets represent purchased assets that also lack physical substance but can be
	separately distinguished from goodwill because of contractual or other legal rights or because the asset is capable of being sold
	or exchanged either on its own or in combination with a related contract, asset or liability.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company performs an
	annual goodwill impairment test, and more frequently if circumstances warrant, in accordance with ASC Topic 350,
<I>
	Intangibles
	&ndash; Goodwill and Other
</I>
	.&nbsp;&nbsp;ASC Topic 350 requires that goodwill and intangible assets that have indefinite lives
	be reviewed for impairment annually, or more frequently if certain conditions occur.&nbsp;&nbsp;Intangible assets with finite lives
	are amortized over the estimated life of the asset, and are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances
	indicated that the carrying value may not be recoverable. Impairment losses, if any, will be recorded as operating expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0PT 0">
	&nbsp;
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 67; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	67
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage68"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Derivative Financial Instruments
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company may enter into derivative contracts for the purposes of managing exposure to
	interest rate risk to meet the financing needs of its customers.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company records all derivatives on the balance
	sheet at fair value.&nbsp;&nbsp;Historically, the Company&#8217;s policy has been not to invest in derivative type investments,
	but, in an effort to meet the financing needs of its customers, the Company has entered into limited fair value hedges.&nbsp;&nbsp;Fair
	value hedges include interest rate swap agreements on fixed rate loans.&nbsp;&nbsp;For derivatives designated as hedging the exposure
	to changes in the fair value of the hedged item, the gain or loss is recognized in earnings in the period of change together with
	the offsetting loss or gain of the hedging instrument.&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value hedges are considered to be highly effective and
	any hedge ineffectiveness was deemed not material.&nbsp;&nbsp;The notional amount of the swaps was $61.3 million at December&nbsp;31,
	2015, and $14.6&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Securities Sold Under Agreements to Repurchase
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company sells securities under agreements to repurchase to meet customer needs for sweep
	accounts.&nbsp;&nbsp;At the point funds deposited by customers become investable, those funds are used to purchase securities owned
	by the Company and held in its general account with the designation of Customers&#8217; Securities.&nbsp;&nbsp;A third party maintains
	control over the securities underlying overnight repurchase agreements.&nbsp;&nbsp;The securities involved in these transactions
	are generally U.S.&nbsp;Treasury or Federal Agency issues.&nbsp;&nbsp;Securities sold under agreements to repurchase generally
	mature on the banking day following that on which the investment was initially purchased and are treated as collateralized financing
	transactions which are recorded at the amounts at which the securities were sold plus accrued interest.&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest rates
	and maturity dates of the securities involved vary and are not intended to be matched with funds from customers.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Bankcard Fee Income
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Periodic bankcard fees, net of direct origination costs, are recognized as revenue on a straight-line
	basis over the period the fee entitles the cardholder to use the card.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Income Taxes
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company accounts for income taxes in accordance with income tax accounting guidance in
	ASC Topic 740,
<I>
	Income Taxes
</I>
	.&nbsp;&nbsp;The income tax accounting guidance results in two components of income tax expense:&nbsp;&nbsp;current
	and deferred. Current income tax expense reflects taxes to be paid or refunded for the current period by applying the provisions
	of the enacted tax law to the taxable income or excess of deductions over revenues.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company determines deferred
	income taxes using the liability (or balance sheet) method.&nbsp;&nbsp;Under this method, the net deferred tax asset or liability
	is based on the tax effects of the differences between the book and tax bases of assets and liabilities, and enacted changes in
	tax rates and laws are recognized in the period in which they occur.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Deferred income tax expense results from changes in deferred tax assets and liabilities between
	periods.&nbsp;&nbsp;Deferred tax assets are recognized if it is more likely than not, based on the technical merits, that the tax
	position will be realized or sustained upon examination.&nbsp;&nbsp;The term more likely than not means a likelihood of more than
	50 percent; the terms examined and upon examination also include resolution of the related appeals or litigation processes, if
	any.&nbsp;&nbsp;A tax position that meets the more-likely-than-not recognition threshold is initially and subsequently measured
	as the largest amount of tax benefit that has a greater than 50 percent likelihood of being realized upon settlement with a taxing
	authority that has full knowledge of all relevant information.&nbsp;&nbsp;The determination of whether or not a tax position has
	met the more-likely-than-not recognition threshold considers the facts, circumstances and information available at the reporting
	date and is subject to management&#8217;s judgment.&nbsp;&nbsp;Deferred tax assets are reduced by a valuation allowance if, based
	on the weight of evidence available, it is more likely than not that some portion or all of a deferred tax asset will not be realized.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company files consolidated income tax returns with its subsidiaries.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 68; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	68
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage69"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Earnings Per Share
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Basic earnings per share are computed based on the weighted average number of shares outstanding
	during each year.&nbsp;&nbsp;Diluted earnings per share are computed using the weighted average common shares and all potential
	dilutive common shares outstanding during the period.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The computation of per share earnings is as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Stock options to purchase 84,780 shares for the year ended December 31, 2013 were not included
	in the earnings per share calculation because the exercise price exceeded the average market price. There were no such shares for
	the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Stock-Based Compensation
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company has adopted various stock-based compensation plans.&nbsp;&nbsp;The plans provide
	for the grant of incentive stock options, nonqualified stock options, stock appreciation rights and bonus stock awards.&nbsp;&nbsp;Pursuant
	to the plans, shares are reserved for future issuance by the Company, upon exercise of stock options or awarding of bonus shares
	granted to directors, officers and other key employees.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	In accordance with ASC Topic 718,
<I>
	Compensation &#8211; Stock Compensation
</I>
	, the fair
	value of each option award is estimated on the date of grant using the Black-Scholes option-pricing model that uses various assumptions.&nbsp;&nbsp;This
	model requires the input of highly subjective assumptions, changes to which can materially affect the fair value estimate.&nbsp;&nbsp;For
	additional information, see Note 13, Employee Benefit Plans.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Subsequent Events
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	As part of the acquisition of Community First, the Company issued 30,852 shares of Senior
	Non-Cumulative Perpetual Preferred Stock, Series A (&#8220;Simmons Series A Preferred Stock&#8221;). The preferred stock is held
	by the United States Department of the Treasury (&#8220;Treasury&#8221;) as the Community First Series C Preferred Stock was issued
	when Community First entered into a Small Business Lending Fund Securities Purchase Agreement with the Treasury.&nbsp;On January
	29, 2016, the Company redeemed all of the preferred stock, including accrued and unpaid dividends.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	On February 19, 2016, the trust and fiduciary business operations of Simmons First Trust
	Company, N.A., a wholly-owned subsidiary of Simmons Bank, were merged into Simmons Bank.
</P>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<FONT STYLE="BACKGROUND-COLOR: YELLOW">
<B>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>

<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	69
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->

<A NAME="eolPage70"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<FONT STYLE="BACKGROUND-COLOR: YELLOW">
<B>
</B>

</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<DIV DATA-TD-STATEMENT-TYPE="NOTE">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 55PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<B>
	NOTE 2:
</B>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 5PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<B>
</B>
<B>
	ACQUISITIONS
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: RULE-PAGE -->
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 3PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 3PT">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 1PT; BORDER-TOP: BLACK 1PT SOLID; WIDTH: 100%">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /RULE-PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<U>
</U>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Liberty Bancshares, Inc.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	On February 27, 2015, Simmons First National Corporation completed the acquisition of Liberty
	Bancshares, Inc. (&#8220;Liberty&#8221;), headquartered in Springfield, Missouri, including its wholly-owned bank subsidiary Liberty
	Bank (&#8220;LB&#8221;). The Company issued 5,181,337 shares of its common stock valued at approximately $212.2 million as of
	February 27, 2015 in exchange for all outstanding shares of Liberty common stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Prior to the acquisition, Liberty conducted banking business from 24 branches located in
	southwest Missouri. Including the effects of the purchase accounting adjustments, the Company acquired approximately $1.1&nbsp;billion
	in assets, approximately $780.7 million in loans including loan discounts and approximately $874.7 million in deposits. The Company
	completed the systems conversion and merged LB into Simmons First National Bank (&#8220;Simmons Bank&#8221; or the &#8220;Bank&#8221;)
	on April 24, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Goodwill of $95.2 million was recorded as a result of the transaction. The merger strengthened
	the Company&#8217;s position in the southwest Missouri market and the Company believes that it will be able to achieve cost savings
	by integrating the two companies and combining accounting, data processing, and other administrative functions all of which gave
	rise to the goodwill recorded. The goodwill will not be deductible for tax purposes.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	A summary, at fair value, of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed in the Liberty transaction,
	as of the acquisition date, is as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
