<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 70; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	70
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage71"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The following is a description of the methods used to determine the fair values of significant
	assets and liabilities presented in the Liberty acquisition above.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Cash and due from banks, time deposits due from banks and federal funds sold
</I>
	&#8211;
	The carrying amount of these assets is a reasonable estimate of fair value based on the short-term nature of these assets. Due
	from banks &#8211; time were acquired with an adjustment to fair value based on rates currently available to the Company for deposits
	in banks with similar maturities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Investment securities
</I>
	&#8211; Investment securities were acquired with an adjustment
	to fair value based upon quoted market prices.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Loans acquired
</I>
	&#8211; Fair values for loans were based on a discounted cash flow
	methodology that considered factors including the type of loan and related collateral, classification status, fixed or variable
	interest rate, term of loan and whether or not the loan was amortizing, and current discount rates.&nbsp;&nbsp;The discount rates
	used for loans are based on current market rates for new originations of comparable loans and include adjustments for liquidity
	concerns.&nbsp;&nbsp;The discount rate does not include a factor for credit losses as that has been included in the estimated
	cash flows.&nbsp;&nbsp;Loans were grouped together according to similar characteristics and were treated in the aggregate when
	applying various valuation techniques.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Premises and equipment
</I>
	&#8211; Bank premises and equipment were acquired with an adjustment
	to fair value, which represents the difference between the Company&#8217;s current analysis of property and equipment values completed
	in connection with the acquisition and book value acquired.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Bank owned life insurance
</I>
	&#8211; Bank owned life insurance is carried at its current
	cash surrender value, which is the most reasonable estimate of fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Goodwill
</I>
	&#8211; The consideration paid as a result of the acquisition exceeded the
	fair value of the assets acquired, resulting in an intangible asset, goodwill, of $95.2 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Core deposit intangible
</I>
	&#8211; This intangible asset represents the value of the
	relationships that Liberty had with its deposit customers.&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value of this intangible asset was estimated based
	on a discounted cash flow methodology that gave appropriate consideration to expected customer attrition rates, cost of the deposit
	base and the net maintenance cost attributable to customer deposits.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Other assets
</I>
	&#8211; The fair value adjustment results from certain assets whose value
	was estimated to be less than book value, such as certain prepaid assets, receivables and other miscellaneous assets. The deferred
	tax asset, included in other assets, is based on 39.225% of fair value adjustments related to the acquired assets and assumed liabilities
	and on a calculation of future tax benefits. The Company also recorded Liberty&#8217;s remaining deferred tax assets and liabilities
	as of the acquisition date.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Deposits
</I>
	&#8211; The fair values used for the demand and savings deposits that comprise
	the transaction accounts acquired, by definition equal the amount payable on demand at the acquisition date.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company
	performed a fair value analysis of the estimated weighted average interest rate of Liberty&#8217;s certificates of deposits compared
	to the current market rates. Based on the results of the analysis, the estimated fair value adjustment was immaterial.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	FHLB borrowings
</I>
	&#8211; The fair value of Federal Home Loan Bank borrowings is estimated
	based on borrowing rates currently available to the Company for borrowings with similar terms and maturities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Subordinated debentures
</I>
	&#8211; The fair value of subordinated debentures is estimated
	based on borrowing rates currently available to the Company for borrowings with similar terms and maturities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Accrued interest and other liabilities
</I>
	&#8211; The adjustment establishes a liability
	for unfunded commitments equal to the fair value of that liability at the date of acquisition.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	During 2015 the Company finalized its analysis of the acquired loans and subordinated debentures
	along with the other acquired assets and assumed liabilities.&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company&#8217;s operating results for 2015 include the operating results of the acquired
	assets and assumed liabilities of Liberty subsequent to the acquisition date.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 71; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	71
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage72"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Community First Bancshares, Inc.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	On February 27, 2015, Simmons First National Corporation completed the acquisition of Community
	First Bancshares, Inc. (&#8220;Community First&#8221;), headquartered in Union City, Tennessee, including its wholly-owned bank
	subsidiary First State Bank (&#8220;FSB&#8221;). The Company issued 6,552,915 shares of its common stock valued at approximately
	$268.3 million as of February 27, 2015, plus $9,974 in cash in exchange for all outstanding shares of Community First common stock.
	The Company also issued $30.9 million of preferred stock in exchange for all outstanding shares of Community First preferred stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Prior to the acquisition, Community First conducted banking business from 33 branches located
	across Tennessee. Including the effects of the purchase accounting adjustments, the Company acquired approximately $1.9&nbsp;billion
	in assets, approximately $1.1 billion in loans including loan discounts and approximately $1.5 billion in deposits. The Company
	completed the systems conversion and merged FSB into Simmons Bank on September 4, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Goodwill of $110.4 million was recorded as a result of the transaction. The merger allowed
	the Company&#8217;s entrance into the Tennessee market and will serve as a launching platform for possible expansion into adjacent
	areas. The Company believes that it will be able to achieve cost savings by integrating the two companies and combining accounting,
	data processing, and other administrative functions. Further the Company believes it can benefit from the addition of Community
	First's small-business lending platform while cross-selling its trust products in Community First&#8217;s market. This combination
	of factors gave rise to the goodwill recorded. The goodwill will not be deductible for tax purposes.
<BR CLEAR="ALL">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	A summary, at fair value, of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed in the Community
	First transaction, as of the acquisition date, is as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 72; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The following is a description of the methods used to determine the fair values of significant
	assets and liabilities presented in the Community First acquisition above.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Cash and due from banks and federal funds sold
</I>
	&#8211; The carrying amount of these
	assets is a reasonable estimate of fair value based on the short-term nature of these assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Investment securities
</I>
	&#8211; Investment securities were acquired with an adjustment
	to fair value based upon quoted market prices.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Loans acquired
</I>
	&#8211; Fair values for loans were based on a discounted cash flow
	methodology that considered factors including the type of loan and related collateral, classification status, fixed or variable
	interest rate, term of loan and whether or not the loan was amortizing, and current discount rates.&nbsp;&nbsp;The discount rates
	used for loans are based on current market rates for new originations of comparable loans and include adjustments for liquidity
	concerns.&nbsp;&nbsp;The discount rate does not include a factor for credit losses as that has been included in the estimated cash
	flows.&nbsp;&nbsp;Loans were grouped together according to similar characteristics and were treated in the aggregate when applying
	various valuation techniques.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
</I>
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 73; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	73
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage74"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Foreclosed assets held for sale
</I>
	&#8211; These assets are presented at the estimated
	present values that management expects to receive when the properties are sold, net of related costs of disposal.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Premises and equipment
</I>
	&#8211; Bank premises and equipment were acquired with an adjustment
	to fair value, which represents the difference between the Company&#8217;s current analysis of property and equipment values completed
	in connection with the acquisition and book value acquired.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Bank owned life insurance
</I>
	&#8211; Bank owned life insurance is carried at its current
	cash surrender value, which is the most reasonable estimate of fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Goodwill
</I>
	&#8211; The consideration paid as a result of the acquisition exceeded the
	fair value of the assets acquired, resulting in an intangible asset, goodwill, of $110.4 million. Goodwill established prior to
	the acquisition was written off.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Core deposit intangible
</I>
	&#8211; This intangible asset represents the value of the
	relationships that Community First had with its deposit customers.&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value of this intangible asset was estimated
	based on a discounted cash flow methodology that gave appropriate consideration to expected customer attrition rates, cost of
	the deposit base and the net maintenance cost attributable to customer deposits.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Other intangibles
</I>
	&#8211; This intangible asset represents the value of the relationships
	that Community First&#8217;s insurance subsidiary had with their customers.&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value of this intangible asset
	was estimated based on a combination of discounted cash flow methodology and a market valuation approach.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Deferred tax asset
</I>
	&#8211; The deferred tax asset is based on 39.225% of fair value
	adjustments related to the acquired assets and assumed liabilities and on a calculation of future tax benefits. The Company also
	recorded Community First&#8217;s remaining deferred tax assets and liabilities as of the acquisition date.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Other assets
</I>
	&#8211; The carrying amount of these assets was deemed to be a reasonable
	estimate of fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Deposits
</I>
	&#8211; The fair values used for the demand and savings deposits that comprise
	the transaction accounts acquired, by definition equal the amount payable on demand at the acquisition date.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company
	performed a fair value analysis of the estimated weighted average interest rate of Community First&#8217;s certificates of deposits
	compared to the current market rates and recorded a fair value adjustment for the difference.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Federal funds purchased and securities sold under agreement to repurchase
</I>
	&#8211;
	The carrying amount of federal funds purchased and securities sold under agreement to repurchase is a reasonable estimate of fair
	value based on the short-term nature of these liabilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	FHLB borrowings
</I>
	&#8211; The fair value of Federal Home Loan Bank borrowings is estimated
	based on borrowing rates currently available to the Company for borrowings with similar terms and maturities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Subordinated debentures
</I>
	&#8211; The fair value subordinated debentures is estimated
	based on borrowing rates currently available to the Company for borrowings with similar terms and maturities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Accrued interest and other liabilities
</I>
	&#8211; The adjustment establishes a liability
	for unfunded commitments equal to the fair value of that liability at the date of acquisition.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	During 2015 the Company finalized its analysis of the acquired loans and subordinated debentures
	along with the other acquired assets and assumed liabilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company&#8217;s operating results for 2015 include the operating results of the acquired
	assets and assumed liabilities of Community First subsequent to the acquisition date.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 74; VALUE: 3 -->

<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	74
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Summary of Unaudited Pro forma Information
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The unaudited pro forma information below for the years ended December 31, 2015 and
	2014 gives effect to the Liberty and Community First acquisitions as if the acquisitions had occurred on January&nbsp;1,
	2014. P
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	ro forma earnings for the year ended December 31, 2015 were adjusted to exclude $7.4
	million of acquisition-related costs, net of tax, incurred by Simmons during 2015. The pro forma financial information is not
	necessarily indicative of the results of operations if the acquisitions had been effective as of this date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
	&nbsp;

<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 15PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	(1)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 5PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	Net
	interest income plus noninterest income.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Consolidated year-to-date 2015 results included approximately $46.0 million of revenue and
	$24.2 million of net income attributable to the Liberty acquisition and $77.3 million of revenue and $33.3 million of net income
	attributable to the Community First acquisition.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Ozark Trust &amp; Investment Corporation
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	On October 29, 2015, Simmons First National Corporation completed the acquisition of Ozark
	Trust &amp; Investment Corporation (&ldquo;Ozark Trust&rdquo;), headquartered in Springfield, Missouri, including its wholly-owned
	non-deposit trust company, Trust Company of the Ozarks (&ldquo;TCO&rdquo;). Simmons issued 339,290 shares of its common stock valued
	at approximately $17.9 million as of October 29, 2015, plus $5.8 million in cash in exchange for all outstanding shares of Ozark
	Trust common stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Prior to the acquisition, Ozark Trust had over $1 billion in assets under management.&nbsp;The
	Company owned 1,000 shares of Ozark Trust&rsquo;s common stock, which it acquired through its acquisition of Liberty in February
	2015. The purchase price is allocated among the net assets of Ozark Trust acquired as appropriate, with the remaining balance being
	reported as goodwill.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	A summary, at fair value, of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed in the Ozark Trust
	transaction, as of the acquisition date, is as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 75; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">

	75
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->

</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage76"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
	The following is a description of the methods used to determine the fair values of
	significant assets and liabilities presented in the Ozark Trust acquisition above.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Cash
</I>
	&#8211; The carrying amount of these assets is a reasonable estimate of fair value
	based on the short-term nature of these assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Investment securities
</I>
	&#8211;. The carrying amount of these assets was deemed to be
	a reasonable estimate of fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Premises and equipment
</I>
	&#8211; Premises and equipment were acquired with an adjustment
	to fair value, which represents the difference between the Company&#8217;s current analysis of property values completed in connection
	with the acquisition and book value acquired.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Goodwill
</I>
	&#8211; The consideration paid as a result of the acquisition exceeded the
	fair value of the assets acquired, resulting in an intangible asset, goodwill, of $13.9 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 1.25IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Other intangibles
</I>
	&#8211; These intangible assets represent the value of the relationships
	that Ozark Trust had with their customers.&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value of these intangible assets was estimated based on a combination
	of discounted cash flow methodology and a market valuation approach.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Other assets
</I>
	&#8211; . The carrying amount of these assets was deemed to be a reasonable
	estimate of fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Deferred tax liability
</I>
	&#8211; The deferred tax liability is based on 39.225% of fair
	value adjustments related to the acquired assets and assumed liabilities and on a calculation of future tax benefits. The Company
	also recorded Ozark Trust&#8217;s remaining deferred tax assets and liabilities as of the acquisition date.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The purchase price allocation and certain fair value measurements remain preliminary due
	to the timing of the acquisition. Management will continue to review the estimated fair values and to evaluate the assumed tax
	positions. The Company expects to finalize its analysis of the acquired assets and assumed liabilities in this transaction over
	the next few months, within one year of the acquisition. Therefore, adjustments to the estimated amounts and carrying values may
	occur.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company&#8217;s operating results for 2015 include the operating results of the acquired
	assets and assumed liabilities of Ozark Trust subsequent to the acquisition date. This acquisition is not considered significant
	to the Company&#8217;s financial statements, and thus no proforma information is presented.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	&nbsp;
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Delta Trust &amp; Banking Corporation
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	On August 31, 2014, Simmons First National Corporation completed the acquisition of
	Delta Trust &amp; Banking Corporation (&#8220;Delta Trust&#8221;), headquartered in Little Rock, Arkansas, including its wholly-owned
	bank subsidiary Delta Trust &amp; Bank (&#8220;DTB&#8221;). Simmons issued 1,629,515 shares of its common stock valued at approximately
	$65.0 million as of August 29, 2014, plus $2.4 million in cash in exchange for all outstanding shares of Delta Trust common stock.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Prior to the acquisition, Delta Trust conducted banking business from 9 branches located
	in central, south and northwest Arkansas. Including the effects of the purchase accounting adjustments, the Company acquired approximately
	$417&nbsp;million in assets, approximately $312 million in loans including loan discounts and approximately $355 million in deposits.
	The Company completed the systems conversion and merged DTB into Simmons Bank on October 24, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 76; VALUE: 3 -->

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The following is a description of the methods used to determine the fair values of significant
	assets and liabilities presented in the Delta Trust acquisition above.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Cash and due from banks and interest bearing balances due from banks
</I>
	&#8211; The carrying
	amount of these assets is a reasonable estimate of fair value based on the short-term nature of these assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Investment securities
</I>
	&#8211; Investment securities were acquired with an adjustment
	to fair value based upon quoted market prices. This adjustment is primarily the result of marking the held-to-maturity securities
	to fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Loans acquired
</I>
	&#8211; Fair values for loans were based on a discounted cash flow
	methodology that considered factors including the type of loan and related collateral, classification status, fixed or variable
	interest rate, term of loan and whether or not the loan was amortizing, and current discount rates.&nbsp;&nbsp;The discount rates
	used for loans are based on current market rates for new originations of comparable loans and include adjustments for liquidity
	concerns.&nbsp;&nbsp;The discount rate does not include a factor for credit losses as that has been included in the estimated cash
	flows.&nbsp;&nbsp;Loans were grouped together according to similar characteristics and were treated in the aggregate when applying
	various valuation techniques.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Foreclosed assets held for sale
</I>
	&#8211; These assets are presented at the estimated
	present values that management expects to receive when the properties are sold, net of related costs of disposal.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 77; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	77
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage78"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Premises and equipment
</I>
	&#8211; Bank premises and equipment were acquired with an adjustment
	to fair value, which represents the difference between the Company&#8217;s current analysis of property values completed in connection
	with the acquisition and book value acquired.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Bank owned life insurance
</I>
	&#8211; Bank owned life insurance is carried at its current
	cash surrender value, which is the most reasonable estimate of fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Goodwill
</I>
	&#8211; The consideration paid as a result of the acquisition exceeded the
	fair value of the assets acquired, resulting in an intangible asset, goodwill, of $29.0 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 1.25IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Core deposit intangible
</I>
	&#8211; This intangible asset represents the value of the
	relationships that Delta Trust had with its deposit customers.&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value of this intangible asset was estimated
	based on a discounted cash flow methodology that gave appropriate consideration to expected customer attrition rates, cost of the
	deposit base and the net maintenance cost attributable to customer deposits.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Other intangibles
</I>
	&#8211; These intangible assets represent the value of the relationships
	that Delta Trust&#8217;s investment subsidiary, insurance subsidiary and trust department had with their customers.&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	fair value of these intangible assets was estimated based on a combination of discounted cash flow methodology and a market valuation
	approach.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Deferred tax asset
</I>
	&#8211; The deferred tax asset is based on 39.225% of fair value
	adjustments related to the acquired assets and assumed liabilities and on a calculation of future tax benefits. The Company also
	recorded Delta Trust&#8217;s remaining deferred tax assets and liabilities as of the acquisition date.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Other assets
</I>
	&#8211; The fair value adjustment results from certain assets whose value
	was estimated to be less than book value, such as certain prepaid assets, receivables and other miscellaneous assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Deposits
</I>
	&#8211; The fair values used for the demand and savings deposits that comprise
	the transaction accounts acquired, by definition equal the amount payable on demand at the acquisition date.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company
	performed a fair value analysis of the estimated weighted average interest rate of Delta Trust&#8217;s certificates of deposits
	compared to the current market rates. Based on the results of the analysis, the estimated fair value adjustment was immaterial.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Federal funds purchased
</I>
	&#8211; The carrying amount of federal funds purchased is
	a reasonable estimate of fair value based on the short-term nature of these liabilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Other borrowings
</I>
	&#8211; The fair value of Federal Home Loan Bank borrowings is estimated
	based on borrowing rates currently available to the Company for borrowings with similar terms and maturities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	During 2015 the Company finalized its analysis of the acquired loans along with the other
	acquired assets and assumed liabilities in this transaction.&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company&#8217;s operating results for 2015 and 2014 include the operating results of
	the acquired assets and assumed liabilities of Delta Trust subsequent to the acquisition date. This acquisition is not considered
	significant to the Company&#8217;s financial statements, and thus no proforma information is presented.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<B>
	Metropolitan National Bank
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	On November 25, 2013, Simmons First National Corporation completed the acquisition of Metropolitan
	National Bank (&ldquo;Metropolitan&rdquo; or &ldquo;MNB&rdquo;), with its principal office located in Little Rock, Arkansas, pursuant
	to a Stock Purchase Agreement between the Company and Rogers Bancshares, Inc. (&ldquo;RBI&rdquo;), in which the Company purchased
	all the stock of Metropolitan for $53.6 million in cash. The acquisition was conducted in accordance with the provisions of Section
	363 of the United States Bankruptcy Code. As part of the acquisition, Metropolitan was merged into Simmons Bank. The Company recorded
	$6.6 million of pre-tax merger costs related to the acquisition.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Prior to the acquisition, Metropolitan conducted banking business from 45 branches located
	in central and northwest Arkansas. Including the effects of the purchase accounting adjustments, the Company acquired approximately
	$884&nbsp;million in assets, approximately $457 million in loans, net of discounts, and $838 million of deposits.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 78; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	78
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage79"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	A summary, at fair value, of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed in the Metropolitan
	transaction, as of the acquisition date, is as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

	--
</TD>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The following is a description of the methods used to determine the fair values of significant
	assets and liabilities presented in the Metropolitan acquisition above.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Cash and due from banks and interest bearing balances due from banks
</I>
	&#8211; The carrying
	amount of these assets is a reasonable estimate of fair value based on the short-term nature of these assets.&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Investment securities
</I>
	&#8211; Investment securities were acquired with a $2.3 million
	adjustment to fair value based upon quoted market prices. This adjustment is primarily the result of marking the held-to-maturity
	securities to fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Loans acquired
</I>
	&#8211; Fair values for loans were based on a discounted cash flow
	methodology that considered factors including the type of loan and related collateral, classification status, fixed or variable
	interest rate, term of loan and whether or not the loan was amortizing, and current discount rates.&nbsp;&nbsp;The discount rates
	used for loans are based on current market rates for new originations of comparable loans and include adjustments for liquidity
	concerns.&nbsp;&nbsp;The discount rate does not include a factor for credit losses as that has been included in the estimated cash
	flows.&nbsp;&nbsp;Loans were grouped together according to similar characteristics and were treated in the aggregate when applying
	various valuation techniques.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Foreclosed assets held for sale
</I>
	&#8211; These assets are presented at the estimated
	present values that management expects to receive when the properties are sold, net of related costs of disposal.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Premises and equipment
</I>
	&#8211; Bank premises and equipment were acquired with a $22.6
	million adjustment to fair value. This represents the difference between current appraisals completed in connection with the acquisition
	and book value acquired.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
</I>
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 79; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	79
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage80"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Goodwill
</I>
	&#8211; The consideration paid as a result of the acquisition exceeded the
	fair value of the assets acquired, resulting in an intangible asset, goodwill, of $17.9 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Core deposit intangible
</I>
	&#8211; This intangible asset represents the value of the
	relationships that Metropolitan had with its deposit customers.&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value of this intangible asset was estimated
	based on a discounted cash flow methodology that gave appropriate consideration to expected customer attrition rates, cost of the
	deposit base and the net maintenance cost attributable to customer deposits.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Deferred tax asset
</I>
	&#8211; The deferred tax asset is based on 39.225% of fair value
	adjustments related to the acquired assets and assumed liabilities and on a calculation of future tax benefits. Metropolitan had
	a full valuation allowance against its deferred tax asset on the acquisition date, since it was more-likely-than-not that it would
	not be realized based on negative evidence which included substantial historical operating losses and a lack of future taxable
	income projections. Metropolitan had approximately $72.8 million in net operating loss carryforward of which approximately $34.0
	is expected to be utilized by the Company under Internal Revenue Code (IRC) Section 382 limitation calculations. The Company also
	recorded Metropolitan&#8217;s remaining deferred tax assets and liabilities along with the deferred taxes associated with the
	purchase price adjustments offset by any IRC Section 382 limitations related to built-in losses.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Other assets
</I>
	&#8211; The fair value adjustment results from certain assets whose value
	was estimated to be less than book value, such a certain prepaid assets, receivables and intangible assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Deposits
</I>
	&#8211; The fair values used for the demand and savings deposits that comprise
	the transaction accounts acquired, by definition equal the amount payable on demand at the acquisition date.&nbsp;&nbsp;The $512,000
	fair value adjustment applied to time deposits results from the estimated weighted average interest rate of Metropolitan&#8217;s
	certificates of deposits being slightly above the current market rates.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Federal funds purchased and other borrowings
</I>
	&#8211; The carrying amount of these
	liabilities is a reasonable estimate of fair value based on the short-term nature of these liabilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Accrued interest and other liabilities
</I>
	&#8211; The fair value used represents the
	adjustment of certain estimated liabilities from Metropolitan.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	During 2014 the Company finalized its analysis of the acquired loans along with the other
	acquired assets and assumed liabilities in this transaction.&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The Company&#8217;s operating results for 2015, 2014 and 2013 include the operating results
	of the acquired assets and assumed liabilities of Metropolitan subsequent to the acquisition date. Due to the significant fair
	value adjustments recorded and the fact Metropolitan was acquired under bankruptcy proceedings, historical results are not believed
	to be relevant to the Company&#8217;s results, and thus no pro forma information is presented.
</P>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
<B>
</B>
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 80; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Securities with limited marketability, such as stock in the Federal Reserve Bank and the
	Federal Home Loan Bank, are carried at cost and are reported as other available-for-sale securities in the table above.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Certain investment securities are valued at less than their historical cost.&nbsp;&nbsp;Total
	fair value of these investments at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, was $872.4 million and $680.5 million, which is approximately
	57.1% and 62.8%, respectively, of the Company&#8217;s combined available-for-sale and held-to-maturity investment portfolios.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 81; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	81
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>

</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage82"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0 0 10PT">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The following table shows the gross unrealized losses and fair value of the Company&#8217;s
	investments with unrealized losses, aggregated by investment category and length of time that individual securities have been in
	a continuous unrealized loss position at December 31:
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	These declines primarily resulted from the rate for these investments yielding less than
	current market rates.&nbsp;&nbsp;Based on evaluation of available evidence, management believes the declines in fair value for
	these securities are temporary. Management does not have the intent to sell these securities and management believes it is more
	likely than not the Company will not have to sell these securities before recovery of their amortized cost basis less any current
	period credit losses.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Declines in the fair value of held-to-maturity and available-for-sale securities below their
	cost that are deemed to be other than temporary are reflected in earnings as realized losses.&nbsp;&nbsp;In estimating other-than-temporary
	impairment losses, management considers, among other things, (i) the length of time and the extent to which the fair value has
	been less than cost, (ii) the financial condition and near-term prospects of the issuer, and (iii) the intent and ability of the
	Company to retain its investment in the issuer for a period of time sufficient to allow for any anticipated recovery in fair value.&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 82; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	82
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage83"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Management has the ability and intent to hold the securities classified as held to maturity
	until they mature, at which time the Company expects to receive full value for the securities.&nbsp;&nbsp;Furthermore, as of December
	31, 2015, management also had the ability and intent to hold the securities classified as available-for-sale for a period of time
	sufficient for a recovery of cost.&nbsp;&nbsp;The unrealized losses are largely due to increases in market interest rates over
	the yields available at the time the underlying securities were purchased.&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value is expected to recover as
	the bonds approach their maturity date or repricing date or if market yields for such investments decline.&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
	does not believe any of the securities are impaired due to reasons of credit quality.&nbsp;&nbsp;Accordingly, as of December 31,
	2015, management believes the impairments detailed in the table above are temporary.&nbsp;&nbsp;Should the impairment of any of
	these securities become other than temporary, the cost basis of the investment will be reduced and the resulting loss recognized
	in net income in the period the other-than-temporary impairment is identified.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Income earned on the above securities for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013,
	is as follows:
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The carrying value, which approximates the fair value, of securities pledged as collateral,
	to secure public deposits and for other purposes, amounted to $840.4 million at December 31, 2015 and $520.4 million at December
	31, 2014. The book value of securities sold under agreements to repurchase amounted to $96.8 million and $100.8 million for December
	31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	There were $350,000 of gross realized gains and $43,000 of realized losses from the sale
	of available for sale securities during the year ended December 31, 2015. There were $199,000 of gross realized gains and $191,000
	of realized losses from the sale of available for sale securities during the year ended December 31, 2014. There were $151,000
	of gross realized gains and $302,000 of realized losses from the sale of available for sale securities during the year ended December
	31, 2013. As part of its strategy related to the 2012 acquisitions, the Company liquidated the acquired mortgage-backed securities,
	resulting in $193,000 of net realized losses during 2013. The income tax expense/benefit related to security gains/losses was 39.225%
	of the gross amounts.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The state and political subdivision debt obligations are primarily non-rated bonds and represent
	small, Arkansas, Illinois, Kansas, Missouri, Tennessee and Texas issues, which are evaluated on an ongoing basis.
</P>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
</P>
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN-TOP: 0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 15PT; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	(1)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 5PT">
</TD>
<TD STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN: JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT">
	See
	Note 5, Loans Acquired, for segregation of loans acquired by loan class. In September
	2015 the Company entered into an agreement with the FDIC to terminate all loss sharing
	agreements.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Loan Origination/Risk Management
</I>
	&#8211; The Company seeks to manage its credit risk
	by diversifying its loan portfolio, determining that borrowers have adequate sources of cash flow for loan repayment without liquidation
	of collateral; obtaining and monitoring collateral; providing an adequate allowance for loans losses by regularly reviewing loans
	through the internal loan review process.&nbsp;&nbsp;The loan portfolio is diversified by borrower, purpose and industry.&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	Company seeks to use diversification within the loan portfolio to reduce its credit risk, thereby minimizing the adverse impact
	on the portfolio, if weaknesses develop in either the economy or a particular segment of borrowers.&nbsp;&nbsp;Collateral requirements
	are based on credit assessments of borrowers and may be used to recover the debt in case of default.&nbsp;&nbsp;Furthermore, factors
	that influenced the Company&#8217;s judgment regarding the allowance for loan losses consists of a five-year historical loss average
	segregated by each primary loan sector.&nbsp;&nbsp;On an annual basis, historical loss rates are calculated for each sector.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Consumer
</I>
	&#8211; The consumer loan portfolio consists of credit card loans and other
	consumer loans.&nbsp;&nbsp;Credit card loans are diversified by geographic region to reduce credit risk and minimize any adverse
	impact on the portfolio. Although they are regularly reviewed to facilitate the identification and monitoring of creditworthiness,
	credit card loans are unsecured loans, making them more susceptible to be impacted by economic downturns resulting in increasing
	unemployment.&nbsp;&nbsp;Other consumer loans include direct and indirect installment loans and overdrafts.&nbsp;&nbsp;Loans in
	this portfolio segment are sensitive to unemployment and other key consumer economic measures.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Real estate
</I>
	&#8211; The real estate loan portfolio consists of construction loans,
	single family residential loans and commercial loans.&nbsp;&nbsp;Construction and development loans (&#8220;C&amp;D&#8221;) and
	commercial real estate loans (&#8220;CRE&#8221;) can be particularly sensitive to valuation of real estate.&nbsp;&nbsp;Commercial
	real estate cycles are inevitable.&nbsp;&nbsp;The long planning and production process for new properties and rapid shifts in business
	conditions and employment create an inherent tension between supply and demand for commercial properties.&nbsp;&nbsp;While general
	economic trends often move individual markets in the same direction over time, the timing and magnitude of changes are determined
	by other forces unique to each market.&nbsp;&nbsp;CRE cycles tend to be local in nature and longer than other credit cycles.&nbsp;&nbsp;Factors
	influencing the CRE market are traditionally different from those affecting residential real estate markets; thereby making predictions
	for one market based on the other difficult.&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally, submarkets within commercial real estate &#8211; such as
	office, industrial, apartment, retail and hotel &#8211; also experience different cycles, providing an opportunity to lower the
	overall risk through diversification across types of CRE loans.&nbsp;&nbsp;Management realizes that local demand and supply conditions
	will also mean that different geographic areas will experience cycles of different amplitude and length.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company
	monitors these loans closely.&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
</I>
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 84; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">
<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; WIDTH: 100%; FONT-SIZE: 10PT">
<TR STYLE="VERTICAL-ALIGN: TOP; TEXT-ALIGN: LEFT">
<TD STYLE="WIDTH: 100%; TEXT-ALIGN: CENTER">
<!-- FIELD: SEQUENCE; TYPE: ARABIC; NAME: PAGENO -->
	84
<!-- FIELD: /SEQUENCE -->
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage85"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	&nbsp;Commercial
</I>
	&#8211; The commercial loan portfolio includes commercial and agricultural
	loans, representing loans to commercial customers and farmers for use in normal business or farming operations to finance working
	capital needs, equipment purchase or other expansion projects.&nbsp;&nbsp;Collection risk in this portfolio is driven by the creditworthiness
	of the underlying borrowers, particularly cash flow from customers&#8217; business or farming operations.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company
	continues its efforts to keep loan terms short, reducing the negative impact of upward movement in interest rates.&nbsp;&nbsp;Term
	loans are generally set up with a one or three year balloon, and the Company has recently instituted a pricing mechanism for commercial
	loans.&nbsp;&nbsp;It is standard practice to require personal guaranties on all commercial loans, particularly as they relate
	to closely-held or limited liability entities.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Nonaccrual and Past Due Loans
</I>
	&#8211; Loans are considered past due if the required
	principal and interest payments have not been received as of the date such payments were due.&nbsp;&nbsp;Loans are placed on nonaccrual
	status when, in management&#8217;s opinion, the borrower may be unable to meet payment obligations as they become due, as well
	as when required by regulatory provisions.&nbsp;&nbsp;Loans may be placed on nonaccrual status regardless of whether or not such
	loans are considered past due.&nbsp;&nbsp;When interest accrual is discontinued, all unpaid accrued interest is reversed. Interest
	income is subsequently recognized only to the extent cash payments are received in excess of principal due.&nbsp;&nbsp;Loans are
	returned to accrual status when all the principal and interest amounts contractually due are brought current and future payments
	are reasonably assured.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Nonaccrual loans, excluding loans acquired, at December 31, 2015 and 2014, segregated by
	class of loans, are as follows:
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
<I>
	Impaired Loans
</I>
	&#8211; A loan is considered impaired when it is probable that the
	Company will not receive all amounts due according to the contractual terms of the loans, including scheduled principal and interest
	payments.&nbsp;&nbsp;This includes loans that are delinquent 90 days or more, nonaccrual loans and certain other loans identified
	by management.&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain other loans identified by management consist of performing loans with specific allocations of
	the allowance for loan losses. Impaired loans are carried at the present value of estimated future cash flows using the loan&#8217;s
	existing rate, or the fair value of the collateral if the loan is collateral dependent.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Impairment is evaluated in total for smaller-balance loans of a similar nature and on an
	individual loan basis for other loans.&nbsp;&nbsp;Impaired loans, or portions thereof, are charged-off when deemed uncollectible.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; TEXT-ALIGN: RIGHT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 86; VALUE: 3 -->
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 6PT; BORDER-BOTTOM: BLACK 4PT SOLID">

</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	At December 31, 2015, and December 31, 2014, impaired loans, net of government guarantees
	and excluding loans acquired, totaled $18.2&nbsp;million and $14.7 million, respectively.&nbsp;&nbsp;Allocations of the allowance
	for loan losses relative to impaired loans were $2.8&nbsp;million and $2.1 million at December 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.&nbsp;&nbsp;Approximately
	$1.2&nbsp;million, $0.8 million and $0.9 million of interest income was recognized on average impaired loans of $16.7 million,
	$17.5 million and $21.6&nbsp;million for 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest recognized on impaired loans on
	a cash basis during 2015, 2014 and 2013 was not material.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Included in certain impaired loan categories are troubled debt restructurings (&#8220;TDRs&#8221;).&nbsp;&nbsp;When
	the Company restructures a loan to a borrower that is experiencing financial difficulty and grants a concession that it would not
	otherwise consider, a &#8220;troubled debt restructuring&#8221; results and the Company classifies the loan as a TDR.&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	Company grants various types of concessions, primarily interest rate reduction and/or payment modifications or extensions, with
	an occasional forgiveness of principal.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Under ASC Topic 310-10-35 &#8211;
<I>
	Subsequent Measurement
</I>
	, a TDR is considered to be
	impaired, and an impairment analysis must be performed.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company assesses the exposure for each modification, either
	by collateral discounting or by calculation of the present value of future cash flows, and determines if a specific allocation
	to the allowance for loan losses is needed.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	Once an obligation has been restructured because of such credit problems, it continues to
	be considered a TDR until paid in full; or, if an obligation yields a market interest rate and no longer has any concession regarding
	payment amount or amortization, then it is not considered a TDR at the beginning of the calendar year after the year in which the
	improvement takes place.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company returns TDRs to accrual status only if (1) all contractual amounts due can reasonably
	be expected to be repaid within a prudent period, and (2) repayment has been in accordance with the contract for a sustained period,
	typically at least six months.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>
<!-- FIELD: PAGE; SEQUENCE: 87; VALUE: 3 -->

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
</P>

<DIV STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS; MARGIN-TOP: 6PT">
	&nbsp;
</DIV>
<!-- FIELD: /PAGE -->
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0">
	The following table presents loans that were restructured as TDRs during the years ended
	December 31, 2015 and 2014, excluding loans acquired, segregated by class of loans.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 10PT; MARGIN: 0; TEXT-INDENT: 0.5IN">
	&nbsp;
